{{Infobox person | name = Ndave David Njokuhttp://ndavedavid.com/ | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | title = Film Producer, Director | birth_place = [[Abraka]], [[Delta state]], Nigeriahttp://ndavedavid.com/ | residence = [[Nigeria]] | occupation = [[Film Maker]] | nationality = Nigerian | citizenship = Nigerian | years_active = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''David Njoku''' (born '''Ndave David Njoku''') is a Nigerian Film Maker, Production Manager with Nollywood Industry.[https://www.facebook.com/public/NDave-David-Njoku Ndava David Njoku][https://talks.friendite.com/meet-ndave-david-njoku-nollywood-filmmaker/ friendite talks with Ndave David]http://ndavedavid.com/ndave/ ==Early life== Ndave hails from Ukelefi in [[Nkanu East]] Local Government Area of [[Enugu state]] but was born and bred in [[Abraka]], [[Delta state]], [[Nigeria]]. He is last child from a family of seven children and grew up without a father owing to the untimely demise when he was just 14 years old.[https://gossip.friendite.com/nollywood-filmmaker-ndave-david-njoku-concludes-a-new-movie/ Nollywood Filmmaker, NDave David Njoku concludes a new movie ...]http://ndavedavid.com/ndave/ ==Education== Ndave did both his Primary and Secondary Education in [[Abraka]], He completed his bachelor's degree in [[Delta State University]] (DELSU).[http://talksfriendite.com/tag/ndave-david-njoku/ talksfriendite.com/tag/ndave-david-njoku/] ==Personal life== Ndave's first audition was in 2004 under the supervision of Mr. Perfect, who cajoled him and told him he had no future in the movie scene. The next day he went back to the audition ground and took a piece out of their script. He used the script to modify and story in his head and wrote a 4-page script. He took the script to St. Paul Catholic Church, [[Delta State University]] and went for an outing with the drama team. From there people began encouraging him to venture into the movie world.[http://frienditetalks1.rssing.com/chan-30116064/latest.php frienditetalks1.rssing.com/chan-30116064/latest.php ]
His hobbies are making researches and playing games.
Ndave's favorite directors are Mr Ifeanyi Ikenyi (Mr. Hollywood) and Mr. Chris Nkem Okafor a.k.a. ChrisNX. His best foreign filmmaker is [[Steven Spielberg]], he has work with Queen [[Collete Nwadike]] Exquisite Face of Universe. ==Career== His first movie was '''SMACK DOWN''', where he co-starred with A-list actors like [[Van Vicker]], [[Chiwetalu Agu]] and [[Uche Jombo]]. He then produced a short film titled '''THE WAR LORD''' and 2008, Ndave wrote, co-directed and also was a co-executive producer alongside Oshilim Gabriel and Oshilim Anthony, a movie, '''WICKED CONSCIENCE''', starring [[Chiwetalu Agu]], John Paul, Uche Elendu, and Emmanuel Ahummadu a.k.a. Labista. The movie had a poor turn out and he went in for a four-year break.
In 2012, Ndave started from scratch as a location manager in Awka, Anambra state. A year later he combined both location manager and the position of production manager. Then he went into Producing again and has made the following movies;
JohnPaul and Rebecca '' •Broken Bottle •Little Calabash •Plantain girl •Ghetto Packaging •Oh Blood Money •Sorrows of Nene •Tears of Nene, etc. ''http://frienditegossip.com/nollywood-filmmaker-ndave-david-njoku-concludes-a-new-movie/
In 2015, Ndave David Njoku co-produced the first ever blockbuster cinema movie in the Eastern region, '''THE LAST KIDNAP'''. The movie was produced by '''KAS-VID''' International and directed by Ifeanyi Ikpeonyi a.k.a. Mr. Hollywood.
This year 2016 gave Ndave the opportunity to shoot his first short cinema film titled '''THE INHALER''' by CD Initiative Films. He also co-produced another blockbuster, '''POLYGAMOUS FAMILY''' starring [[Pete Edochie]], Remi Ohajianya, Imet Goodluck .a.k.a. Tallest man. The film was produced by OG Best International.
Completed a new movie starring [[Nkem Owoh]], Tana Adelena Egbo and others, for '''AMACO''' Investment and just concluded a movie project for Dekross Productions, he has also work with [[Kingsley Onyenma]].http://www.nairaland.com/2737285/see-pictures-special-effects-nollywood He has worked with different Movies Actors, Actress, Models and other Entertainment Industry.https://www.facebook.com/public/NDave-David-Njoku[https://twitter.com/ndavedavid/ Ndave twitter][http://instagram.com/ndavedavid/ Ndave David Njoku][https://talks.friendite.com/meet-ndave-david-njoku-nollywood-filmmaker/ MEET NDAVE DAVID NJOKU, NOLLYWOOD FILMMAKER ...Nollywood Filmmaker, NDave David Njoku concludes a new movie ...]http://talksfriendite.com/tag/ndave-david-njoku/ ==References== == External links == *[https://www.ndavedavid.com/ Ndave David Njoku ] official website. *[https://www.facebook.com/ndaved/ Ndave David Njoku ] on [[Facebook]] *[https://twitter.com/ndavedavid/ Ndave David Njoku ] on [[Twitter]] *[http://instagram.com/ndavedavid/ Ndave David Njoku ] on [[Instagram]] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Njoku, Ndave}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English-language film directors]] [[Category:Nigerian film directors]] [[Category:Nigerian people]] [[Category:Nigerian male film actors]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Igbo male actors]] [[Category:21st-century Nigerian male actors]] [[Category:Nigerian male television actors]]

[[Image:sw8cams.jpg|thumb|SuperWASP cameras are mounted on an OMI [[equatorial mount]]]]
'''Optical Mechanics, Inc.''' or '''OMI''' is a high-end American [[telescope]] and optics instrument manufacturer. OMI was founded in 2002 and produces observatory telescopes, [[Lidar]] telescopes, optical tube assemblies, telescope mirrors and reflective coatings for mirrors. OMI mirrors are used by other telescope makers such as [[Obsession Telescopes]].<ref>http://www.obsessiontelescopes.com/optics/index.html</ref> Also taking on custom projects, they produced the 48-inch Dob, a {{convert|48.875|in|mm|adj=mid|-diameter}} [[aperture]], {{f/}}4, [[Dobsonian]] telescope called "Barbarella" and featured in [[Astronomy Technology Today]] magazine (June 2008 Issue).<ref>http://www.lowreyobservatory.com/</ref><ref>http://www.opticalmechanics.com/48Dob/index.html</ref> OMI is located in the US state of [[Iowa]]. OMI procured the assets of the former optics company Torus Technologies.<reF>[https://www.photonics.com/Article.aspx?AID=13772]</ref><Ref>[http://www.leagle.com/decision/2003856297BR559_1788/IN%20RE%20MULHERIN]</ref> OMI has an optics shop where it does work on telescopes.<ReF>[http://www.leagle.com/decision/2003856297BR559_1788/IN%20RE%20MULHERIN]</ref>
OMI produced the 60 cm, f/10 telescope for [[TUBITAK National Observatory]] in [[Turkey]]. OMI built the telescope mount for the [[SuperWASP]] telescope.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.superwasp.org/|title=SuperWASP Homepage|work=superwasp.org}}</ref> The [[Robotic telescope]] [[Rigel Telescope]] was finished in 2002, a Talon program controlled 0.37-meter (14.5 in) F/14 telescope.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sierrastars.com/gp/Rigel/RigelTelescope.aspx|title=About Rigel|work=sierrastars.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090130014917/http://sierrastars.com/gp/Rigel/RigelTelescope.aspx|archivedate=2009-01-30|df=}}</ref>
OMI helped re-furbish the Gueymard Research Telescope at The George Observatory at [[Brazos Bend State Park]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/George-Observatory-turning-eyes-toward-the-skies-6243942.php|title=George Observatory turning eyes toward the skies with restored telescope|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> The telescope's mirror was degrading after many decades of use and exposure.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/George-Observatory-turning-eyes-toward-the-skies-6243942.php|title=George Observatory turning eyes toward the skies with restored telescope|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> The 10 ton 36 inch aperture telescope was acquired from [[Louisiana State University]] in 1990.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/George-Observatory-turning-eyes-toward-the-skies-6243942.php|title=George Observatory turning eyes toward the skies with restored telescope|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> It is a [[cassegrain reflector|cassegrain]] telescope, and one of the largest that is open to public viewing through an eyepiece.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/George-Observatory-turning-eyes-toward-the-skies-6243942.php|title=George Observatory turning eyes toward the skies with restored telescope|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> OMI had to strip off aluminum coating and re-surface the glass mirror.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/George-Observatory-turning-eyes-toward-the-skies-6243942.php|title=George Observatory turning eyes toward the skies with restored telescope|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> The mirror was ground to a hyperbolic shape, and the refurbishment was conducted in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/George-Observatory-turning-eyes-toward-the-skies-6243942.php|title=George Observatory turning eyes toward the skies with restored telescope|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>
OMI refited the 0.8 cm telescope at [[McDonald Observatory]] in 2011 to 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mcdonaldobservatory.org/research/telescopes/08-meter-telescope|title=0.8-meter Telescope {{!}} McDonald Observatory|website=mcdonaldobservatory.org|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> Another telescope OMI built was the CESAR Cebreros Optical Telescope at Cebreros observatory at the ESA Deep Space Tracking Station <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/cesar/cebreros-observatories|title=CESAR > Cebreros Observatory|website=www.cosmos.esa.int|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref> The telescope is a Cassegrain design with 50cm and a F/10 ratio.<ref>[http://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/cesar/cebreros-observatories]</ref> (see also [[Cebreros Station]])
==OMI Evolution-30== OMI developed the 30-inch mirror for [[Obsession Telescopes]]'s 30-inch reflector <ref>http://www.obsessiontelescopes.com/obsessed/30-inch-owners.html</ref> When Obsession withdrew from the 30-inch market, OMI still wanted to offer their 30-inch mirrors.<ref name=omi30/> Drawing on help from Obsession Telescopes and their own experience with the OMI 48-inch telescope, they offered the OMI Evolution-30 in 2009.<ref name=omi30>/http://www.opticalmechanics.com/evolution_dobs/Evo-30_intro/index.html</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.opticalmechanics.com/index.html OMI]

[[File:Paul Atherton.jpg|thumb|Paul Atherton, producer]]
'''Paul Atherton''' (born 20 March 1968) was managing director of Simple (TV) Productions which folded in the early 2000s <ref>[http://www.simpletvproductions.co.uk Simple (TV) Productions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220143220/http://simpletvproductions.co.uk/ |date=20 February 2009 }}</ref> and its sister not-for-profit company, Q&D Productions Limited.<ref>[http://www.quickanddirtyproductions.co.uk Q&D Productions Limited] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004112358/http://www.quickanddirtyproductions.co.uk/ |date=4 October 2011 }}</ref>{{cite web | author = British Film Archive | year = 2007 | title = The Ballet of Change at British Film Archive | url = http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/842527}}</ref> <ref name = "BFI - Paul Atherton">{{cite web | author = British Film Archive | year = 2007 | title = Paul Atherton at British Film Archive | url = http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/individual/1344295}}</ref> and had his video diary taken into the permanent collection of the [[Museum of London]] <ref name = "LondonLive interview with Paul Atherton 8th January 2016">{{cite web | author = LondonLive | year = 2016 | title = News interview with Paul Atherton about Our London Lives at the Museum of London | url =https://about.me/paulatherton}}</ref>
==Early life== Atherton was three months old when he was abandoned in a tent at a disused airport in [[Cardiff]] but placed with a white foster family shortly after.<ref name = "Rhymney Valley foster child reunited with social worker that placed him with parents">{{cite web | author = Western Mail Newspaper | date = 26 March 2013 | title = Rhymney Valley foster child reunited with social worker that placed him with parents | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/local-news/rhymney-valley-foster-child-reunited-2024404}}</ref>
He grew up in the village of [[Ystrad Mynach]] in [[South Wales]] <ref name = "How a Rookie Social Worker Turned My Life Around">{{cite web | author = South Wales Echo Newspaper | date = 14 September 2012 | title = How a Rookie Social Worker Turned My Life Around | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/local-news/paul-atherton-how-rookie-social-2024067}}</ref> attending [[Lewis School Pengam]] until the age of 16.<ref name = "Channel 4 Television: 4thought.tv">{{cite web | author = Channel 4: 4thought.tv | year = 2011 | title = Should White Parents adopt Non-White Children | url = http://www.4thought.tv/4thoughts/0187-Paul-Atherton-Should-white-parents-adopt-non-white-children- | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110727230834/http://www.4thought.tv/4thoughts/0187-Paul-Atherton-Should-white-parents-adopt-non-white-children- | archivedate=27 July 2011}}</ref>
He left home at 15, when he spent time in children's homes<ref name = "The Big Issue Magazine">{{cite web | author = The Big Issue Magazine | year = 2008 | title = TV Calling | url = http://www.keepandshare.com/doc/view.php?id=931042&da=y}}</ref> and completed his "O" Levels. At 16 he set up home on his own, against the wishes of Social Services and started work on a [[Youth Training Scheme]] in [[Howells (department store)]] considered the best in the country <ref name = "Observer Magazine">{{citation | author = Observer Magazine | date = 10 September 1987 | title = Youth Training Schemes The Good & The Bad}}</ref>
After a traumatic event at the age of 18 he became homeless and lived on the streets, but by 20 he'd recovered his life and bought his first flat.
He was appointed the Welsh Young Conservatives Press Officer later that year and focused on addressing the issues of Homelessness with a programme working with Sixth Forms in Schools in Cardiff. <ref name = "New Press Office for Welsh Young Conservatives">{{citation | author = South Wales Echo | date = 23 February 1989 | title = New Press Officer for Welsh Young Conservatives}}</ref>
At the age of 21, Atherton was diagnosed with [[chronic fatigue syndrome]] (CFS, often called myalgic encephalomyelitis in the United Kingdom),<ref name="What about ME? Film">{{cite video | people = | year = 2010 | title = "What About ME?" | url = http://vimeo.com/10536172 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100404033802/http://vimeo.com/10536172 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 4 April 2010 | format = | medium = Trailer | trans_title = | publisher = Double D Productions | location = United Kingdom | accessdate = 2012-05-16 | time = 3:57 | id = | isbn = | oclc = | quote = | ref = | df = dmy-all }}</ref> and still suffers today.<ref name = "Sacred Cinema Film">{{cite video | year = 2012 | title = "Sacred Cinema" | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2204582/ | format = HD | medium = Film | publisher = | location = Canada | accessdate =2012-05-16 | time = |}}</ref>
He attended [[Cardiff Business School]], and obtained a BSc Honours Degree in Business Administration as a mature student in 1994.<ref name = "Cardiff University Magazine">{{cite web | author = Cardiff University Magazine | year = 2008 | title = A Capital Achievement | url = http://www.cardiffnetwork.cf.ac.uk/document.doc?id=23}}</ref>
While studying he set up a mail order company specialising in silk lingerie called "A Touch of Silk" in 1994 and became [[Vogue Magazine]]'s Valentine gift of choice the following year <ref name = "Sun Newspaper">{{citation | author = Sun Newspaper | year = 1994 | title = Charles Props Up Naughty Knickers}} </ref> <ref name = "Vogue Magazine">{{citation | author = Vogue Magazine | year = 1995 | title = The Perfect Valentines Gift}} </ref>
==Career== His television career began at Prospect Pictures, working on their live five-day-a-week cookery programme ''[[Good Food Live]]''<ref name = "Industry News">{{cite web | author = Industry News | date = 31 May 2002 | title = Skillset Arrange a "Lucky Break" at Production Show | url = http://www.4rfv.co.uk/industrynews/1535/skillset_arrange_a_lucky_break_at_production_show}}</ref> before setting up his production companies in 2004.<ref name = "Broadcast Magazine">{{cite web | author = Broadcast Magazine | year = 2007 | title = Capital Shouldn't Cause Offense | url = http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/broadcast-letters-november-9/224990.article}}</ref>
In 2005 his first production ''[[Silent Voices (film)|Silent Voices]]'', a docudrama about domestic violence, premiered on British television, based on the real-life accounts of children who had witnessed their parents being beaten.
In 2007 Atherton was the first and only producer-director to have had his work shown on the Piccadilly Circus Coca-Cola Billboard with [[The Ballet of Change]], a ballet of film and music telling the histories of four of London's most historic landmarks. {{fact|date=November 2018}}
In February 2009 he worked with Wil Johnson ([[BBC]], star of ''[[Waking the Dead (TV series)|Waking the Dead]]'') and [[Robert Cavanah]] ([[Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life|Tomb Raider]]) on a short film entitled ''[[Colour Blind 2009|Colour Blind]]'', to bring attention to a UK audience, the dangers of seeing racism everywhere. He made up his White lead in [[Golliwog]] ([[black face]]) make-up to make the point.<ref name = "Colourful Radio">{{cite web | author = Colourful Radio | date = 26 March 2009 | title = The Breakfast Show | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9G5xihvChc}}</ref>
On 2 August 2009, Atherton started pre-production on ''A Thousand Voices for a Broken System'', a new format of documentary film that will originally take place on the [[World wide web|Web]] and eventually be edited for cinema.
Prompted by his own experiences<ref name = "Wheels of Misfortune">{{cite web | author = Private Eye Magazine | year = 2010 | title = Wheels of Misfortune | url =http://www.keepandshare.com/doc/2054460/private-eye-magazine-wheels-of-misfortune-paul-atherton-s-story-07-07-10-pdf-july-8-2010-11-3?dn=y}}</ref><ref name = "Hostel Takeover">{{cite web | author = Private Eye Magazine | year = 2010 | title = Hostel Takeover | url =http://issuu.com/paulathertonsimpleproductions/docs/private_eye_magazine_hostel_takeover_paul_atherton}}</ref> the premise of the film is to interview 1,000 people from across the UK who have been failed by the Welfare, NHS or Social Services in the past 10 years, in order to highlight the issues of the most vulnerable people in society.
On 6 September 2010, Atherton announced that he had signed video games writer [[Rhianna Pratchett]] to write his first feature film. ''Vigilia'' (a working title) was due to shoot in 2013 but ultimately didn't get off the ground.<ref name = "Gaming writer Rhianna Pratchett moves onto first feature film">{{cite web | author = Screen International | year = 2010 | title = Gaming writer Rhianna Pratchett moves onto first feature film | url =http://www.screendaily.com/news/production/gaming-writer-rhianna-pratchett-moves-onto-first-feature-film/5017796.article}}</ref> <ref name = "Feature Film Vigilia Announces Development Phase">{{cite web | author = IMDb | year = 2012 | title = Viglia | url =https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2375712/}}</ref>
In 2012 he was invited to make a documentary about the founding of a [[Free school (England)]] by head teacher [[Katharine Birbalsingh]] in the borough of [[Lambeth]] in London, though this school never came to being he was latterly invited back in 2015 when the [[Michaela Community School]] in [[Wembley]] eventually opened.<ref name = "Why it's right for a head to demand lunch money - and high standards">{{cite web | author = The Guardian Newspaper | year = 2016 | title = Why it's right for a head to demand lunch money - and high standards | url =https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/aug/03/headteacher-right-demand-lunch-money-high-standards}}</ref>
Atherton began work on ''The Feminist Car Commercial'', a campaigning film designed to be a springboard for public debate about the objectification of women in advertising and marketing. He managed to raise a £1Million in kind support from suppliers, crew and cast. Shooting was completed in July 2013.<ref name = "Soho Rushes">{{cite web | author = Soho Rushes Short, Dana knight | date = August 2013 | title = How to Shoot a £1m Car Commercial on a Zero Budget. | url =http://sohoshorts.wordpress.com/2013/08/22/how-to-shoot-a-1-million-car-commercial-on-a-zero-budget/}}</ref> <ref name = "IDEA">{{cite web | author = IDEA, Dana knight | date = August 2013 | title = How to Shoot a £1m Car Commercial on a Zero Budget. | url =http://danaisknight.wordpress.com/2013/08/20/how-to-shoot-a-one-million-worth-car-commercial-on-a-zero-budget/}}</ref>
[[Our London Lives]] opened in The [[Museum of London]] on Friday 8 January 2016 and closed on 11 February 2016. Atherton's personal but professionally recorded visits of his estranged son's visit to London over the past 16 years (1999 - 2015) was shown as part of Recording A Life exhibition in the Show Space gallery and subsequently became the first Video Diary ever taken into the Museum's permanent collection <ref name = "Our London Lives">{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton, Q&D Productions | date = January 2016 | title = Our London Lives | url =https://about.me/paulatherton}}</ref> <ref name = "LondonLive interview with Paul Atherton 8th January 2016">{{cite web | author = LondonLive | year = 2016 | title = News interview with Paul Atherton about Our London Lives at the Museum of London | url =https://about.me/paulatherton}}</ref>
On 21 October 2016 Paul Atherton began living in a car in London's Zone 1 to prompt a media campaign to address the failings of the [[Department for Work and Pensions|DWP]] in the UK. In conjunction with [[Ken Loach]]'s film [[I, Daniel Blake]] he's entitled the project #LivingInACar and in conjunction with #WeAreAllDanielBlake Twitter hashtag is sharing his Bi-Weekly Vlogs over YouTube and latterly [[London Live]].<ref name="LondonLive interview with Paul Atherton 8th January 2016"/> <ref name = "Living In A Car">{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton, Q&D Productions | date = November 2016 | title = Living In A Car | url =https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TCAAfjymvIg}}</ref>
In January 2017 he was appointed a Judge on the inaugural ''Muybridge Short Film Festival'' <ref name="Muybridge Short Film Festival">{{cite web | author = Paul Hughes | date = January 2017 | title = Muybridge Short Film Festival | url = http://www.muybridgeshortfilmfest.co.uk/index.php/judge-biographies/}}</ref> which was screened in the [[Rose Theatre, Kingston]] which is situated next to the birthplace of [[Eadweard Muybridge]] the "Father of Cinema" and the person the [[Short Film]], [[Film Festival]] was named after.
He appeared as a pundit in the first two premiere episodes of Meet The Critics on [[Colourful Radio]] on Friday 2 & 9 June 2017. The shows were broadcast at 21:00 GMT and subsequently available online and presented by [[British Urban Film Festival]] founder Emmanuel Anyiam-Osigwe <ref name="Meet The Critics">{{cite web | author = Colourful Radio | date = May 2017 | title = The new film host on Colourful Radio is Emmanuel Anyiam-Osigwe | url=http://www.colourfulradio.com/content/press/28641=}}</ref> <ref name="Paul Atherton on Meet The Critics"> {{cite web | author = Emmanuel Anyiam-Osigwe | date = May 2017 | title = The Line Up for Friday's Debut of Meet The Critics | url = https://twitter.com/aaafilmandtv/status/8691389006059479061=}}</ref>. He returned as a regular pundit for all ten episodes of the second season which began with a Live audience event on 16 February 2018 19:00 GMT to mark the premiere of the [[Marvel Studios|Marvel]]/[[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Disney Studios]] film [[Black Panther (film)|Black Panther]] <ref name="EXCLUSIVE: ‘Meet The Critics’ - live in the studio - for the Black Panther...">{{cite web | author = Colourful Radio | date = January 2018 | title = Meet The Critics’ - live in the studio - for the Black Panther special | url=https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/exclusive-meet-the-critics-live-in-the-studio-for-the-black-panther-special-on-colourful-radio-tickets-42769374350=}}</ref> <ref name="Meet The Critics with Paul Atherton">{{cite web | author = Emmanuel Anyiam-Osigwe | date = January 2018 | title = EXCLUSIVE: ‘Meet The Critics’ - live in the studio - for the Black Panther... | url = https://twitter.com/_MeetTheCritics/status/953197676614619136=}}</ref>
Atherton made his Theatre Directing debut in the European Premiere of Samantha Garman's selection of short plays entitled Human Mating Dance at the [[Old Red Lion Theatre]] in Angel, Islington, London, Saturday 16 July 2017 directing the short entitled "Coffee Shop Real Estate" and starring in an acting role in another of the collection "Thou Shalt Not Covet" playing Richard. <ref name="Human Mating Dance">{{cite web | author = Savina Sedghi | date = June 2017 | title = Paul Atherton's inauguration as a Theatre Director | url = https://www.humanmatingdance.com/thou-shalt-not-covet/}}</ref>
==Personal life== Atherton appeared as a voluntary performer in the London [[2012 Summer Olympics closing ceremony]], dancing in both the Rush Hour and Street Party sections.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://my.telegraph.co.uk/paulatherton/paulatherton/3/what-is-the-olympic-legacy-a-view-from-a-closing-ceremony-volunteer/|title='What is the Olympic Legacy:A View from a Closing Ceremony Volunteer|first=Paul|last=Atherton|date=13 August 2012|accessdate=20 August 2012|publisher=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref name = "Inside a Truck in the Closing Ceremony of the London 2012 Olympic Games Trailer">{{cite video | people = | year = 2012 | title = "Inside a Truck in the Closing Ceremony of the London 2012 Olympic Games" | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tH_tFc4t0PA | format = | medium = Trailer | trans_title = | publisher = Simple Productions | location = United Kingdom | accessdate = 20 August 2012 | time = 0:09 | id = | isbn = | oclc = | quote = | ref =}}</ref><ref name="A Symphony of British Music, London 2012 Closing Ceremony 12 August 2012">{{cite web |author = LOCOG |year = 2012 |title = A Symphony of British Music, London 2012 Closing Ceremony 12 August 2012 Programme |url = http://www.london2012.com/mm/Document/Documents/General/01/39/69/96/OCCVolunteers_Neutral.pdf }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
His real life experiences of childhood abandonment helped inspire the character of Eric Parkhill in [[Wendy Perriam]]'s novel ''Broken Places'' (2011)<ref name = "Broken Places">{{cite web | author = Wendy Perriam | year = 2011 | title = Broken Places | url = http://www.wendyperriam.com/novel16.html}}</ref> and his interaction with a Renault car dealership, resulting in his buying a Skoda, is retold as one of the negotiation case studies in Clive Rich's ''The Yes Book'' (2013).<ref name = "The Yes Book">{{cite web | author = Clive Rich | year = 2013 | title = The Yes Book | url = http://cliverich.com/the-yes-book/}}</ref>
As a mixed-race child of White foster parents, he also comments publicly on the issues of race and adoption, often appearing on television and in the press.<ref name = "The Barriers to Adoption">{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 4 May 2012 | title = Evening Standard: The Barriers to Adoption | url = http://standardonline.newspaperdirect.com/epaper/showlink.aspx?bookmarkid=59M3IU4X3HS&linkid=bd2b0ae9-099b-4e24-aff6-67e532a7445b&pdaffid=KYFS6gL9yyU6qnwlKNlO9w%3d%3d | accessdate = 4 May 2012}}</ref> <ref name = "The Great British Black Invasion">{{cite web | author = Channel 4 | date = 5 August 2006 | title = Channel 4: The Great British Black Invasion <!--| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NoHDXcstZDA -->| url = http://www.junipertv.co.uk/television/the-great-british-black-invasion.html | accessdate = 8 August 2006}}</ref> <ref name = "Sunday Morning Live">{{cite web | author = BBC | date = 9 October 2011 | title = BBC: Sunday Morning Live | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b015ynr7 | accessdate = 11 October 2011}}</ref>
He has been involved in many campaigns to prevent historic buildings from demolition,<ref name = "Save Burlington Arcade - Letter to Planning Committee">{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 27 March 2012 | title = I Object to the Application 12/01433/LBC | url = https://www.facebook.com/saveburlingtonarcade/posts/399993126695539 | access-date =19 February 2016}}</ref><ref name = "Save 21 Albermarle Street (Royal Institution) - Correspondence to Mayor of Westminster">{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 18 January 2013 | title = Don't Worry Royal Institution - We the Public Won't Let this Happen | url = https://www.facebook.com/louise.r.hyams/posts/524951770860424 | access-date =19 February 2016}}</ref><ref name = "London Vs The Rest of the UK - Who wins?">{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | publisher = Guardian Newspaper | date = 29 January 2014 | title = London Vs The Rest of UK - Who wins?: Comments | url = https://profile.theguardian.com/user/id/3459955 | access-date =19 February 2016}}</ref> including attempting to occupy the [[Art Deco]] [[Odeon Cinemas|Odeon Cinema]] in [[Kensington]], with fellow film-maker Paul Wiffen in September 2015 <ref name = "Campaigners in last-ditch bid to save historic Odeon Cinema"> {{cite web | author = Mark Blunden | date = 4 September 2015 | title = Evening Standard: Campaigners in last-ditch bid to save historic Odeon cinema | url = http://standardonline.newspaperdirect.com/epaper/showlink.aspx?bookmarkid=3TYGCIGRFQD6&linkid=f57b6c48-df73-4684-8897-206211a61034&pdaffid=KYFS6gL9yyU6qnwlKNlO9w%3d%3d}}</ref>
Since 1997 he hosts 4 parties a year across various London locations whose entertainers have included the cast of the London Musical Chicago, Guinness World Record Holder Fire Eater & Burlesque Champions having made claim to opening the first parties at Dandelyan, Radio Bar, Disrepute & The Yacht London. <ref name = "Paul Atherton Advantages of Age Profile"> {{cite web | author = Suzanne Noble | date =8 August 2017 | title = Advantages of Age | url = https://advantagesofage.com/4172-2/}}</ref> <ref name = "Paul Atherton's Venue interview in Events Magazine"> {{cite web | author = Brea Carter | date = 22 January 2016 | title = Event Magazine | url = http://www.eventmagazine.co.uk/securing-space-venue-trends-rise/venues/article/1380407}}</ref>
He played a speaking role in the final theatrical production run of [[You Me Bum Bum Train]] an immersive theatre performance based in a disused book shop on [[Charing Cross Road]] from 25 February 2016 to 29 April 2016 <ref name = "BECTU Launches Probe Into Exploitative Bum Bun Train Internships"> {{cite web | author = David Hutchinson | date = 4 September 2015 | title = The Stage: BECTU Launches Probe Into Exploitative Bum Bun Train Internships | url = https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2016/bectu-launches-probe-exploitative-bum-bum-train-internships/}}</ref>
He won a lyric competition run by former [[Australian Idol]] winner [[Natalie Gauci]] and received the prize of seeing the song performed by her at [[TED (conference)|Ted]]x London in the [[Science Museum London]] on Friday 17 June 2016. <ref name = "Thanks to Winning Natalie Gauci's Lyric Competition"> {{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 17 June 2016 | title = Thanks to Winning Natalie Gauci's Lyric Competition | url =https://twitter.com/LondonersLondon/status/743819654108422144/}}</ref>
As a Fugalist (someone who lives life to the fullest on little to no money) he assisted [[The Guardian|Guardian]] Newspaper Journalist Michelle Mcgagh in her ''Year of No Spending'' project, showing her how to get free theatre tickets in Central London, as well as access to free film screenings & comedy. He was later cited in her book published on the subject under his twitter account handle @LondonersLondon. <ref name = "The No Spending Year">{{cite web | author = Michelle McGagh | year = 2016 | title = The No Spending Year: How You Can Spend Less & Live More | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=W_cZDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT51&lpg=PT51&dq=michelle+mcgagh+@LondonersLondon&source=bl&ots=oN7xqWgMBx&sig=oJc69F71a7O0fZ-vQYI11mD6UR0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtzZX91LnaAhWCLcAKHaR5CyEQ6AEIajAG#v=onepage&q=michelle%20mcgagh%20%40LondonersLondon&f=false }}</ref>
He performed in the 50th [[Notting Hill Carnival]] in 2016 playing steel pans with Britain's first Steel Band, ''Nostalgia'' on both 28 & 29 August 2016 <ref name ="Notting Hill Carnival 2016 Aug 28th Steel Band jamming 'Classic Lord Kitch' on the Road">{{cite AV media | people = Paul Atherton | date = 28 August 2016 | title = Notting Hill Carnival 2016 Aug 28th Steel Band jamming "Classic Lord Kitch" on the Road | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UaZFqC2ACbE | access-date =14 October 2016 | time = 0:17 | location =Notting Hill | publisher =Nostalgia Steel Band }}</ref>
In January 2017 he became one of the founding contributors to the UK launch of [[Jolabokaflod]] recommending [[David Liss]]'s book a [[Conspiracy of Paper]] <ref name = "Jolabokaflod"> {{cite web | author = Jolablokafod | date = 20 January 2017 | title = Acknowledgements | url= https://jolabokaflod.org/book-bulletin/acknowledgements/}}</ref>
Atherton delivered his inaugural speech in the [[Palace of Westminster]] on Tuesday 28 March 2017 as part of a debate into [[Bob Blackman (politician)]]'s [[Homelessness Reduction Bill 2016-17]]. Describing his firsthand experiences of homelessness as a guest of [[Molly Samuel]] and Nic Careem's Blue Sky Network initiative. <ref name = "Paul Atherton Speaking at House of Commons">{{cite video | people = | year = 2017 | title = "Paul Atherton Speaking at House of Commons on issue of Homelessness" | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3xbxRe9Ud64/ | format = | medium = film | trans_title = | publisher = Q&D Productions (Not-For-Profit) | location = United Kingdom | accessdate = 29 March 2017 | time = | id = | isbn = | oclc = | quote = | ref =}}</ref>
In October 2017 he became a Film Captain for American Journalist [[Jennifer Brea]]'s documentary about the condition they both suffer [[Chronic Fatigue Syndrome]], [[Unrest (2017 film)]] assisting with marketing & making an appearance at the [[British Film Institute]] Preview screening as part of the Woman with a Movie Camera strand. <ref name = "Don't Miss This Brilliant Documentary">
{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 18 October 2017 | title = Monday Preview Unrest Film got Standing Ovation. Don't miss this brilliant Documentary | url = https://twitter.com/LondonersLondon/status/920589602028650496}}</ref>
Later that month he also began contributing to the online publication the [[Londonist]] his first article tackled the differences between [[Millennials]] and the seemingly more entertaining older generations in the city <ref name = "My 50-something Friends Are Far More Interesting Than Boring Old Millennials">
{{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 17 October 2017 | title = The Londonist, My 50-something Friends Are Far More Interesting Than Boring Old Millennials | url = https://londonist.com/london/opinion/my-50-something-friends-are-far-more-interesting-than-boring-millenials}}</ref>
In December 2017 Atherton was one of three winners (out of the 7) to complete the four day Marathon of the entire screening of [[HBO]]'s [[Game of Thrones]] Television Series from season 1 to 7 held in the [[Prince Charles Cinema]] in [[Leicester Square]] he had never seen the show before. <ref name ="Could You Watch All Of Game of Thrones in One Go? These Fans Are...">{{cite AV media | people = Paul Atherton | date = 28 November 2017 | title = Could You Watch All Of Game of Thrones in One Go? These Fans Are... | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UaZFqC2ACbE | access-date =1 February 2018 | time = 1:11 | location =Prince Charles Cinema, Leicester Square | publisher =Time Out London Magazine }}</ref> <ref name ="The Long Winter:'Game of Thrones' Fans in four-day Viewing marathon">{{cite AV media | people = Paul Atherton | date = 28 November 2017 | title = The Long Winter:'Game of Thrones' Fans in four-day Viewing marathon | url = https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-television-gameofthrones-marathon/the-long-winter-game-of-thrones-fans-in-four-day-viewing-marathon-idUKKBN1DU38H | access-date =17 January 2018 | time = 1:11 | location =Prince Charles Cinema, Leicester Square | publisher =Reuters News Agency }}</ref>
In August 2018 he announced he was now living in London's Heathrow Airport due to his long-term homelessness
In September 2018 he conjoined with the ''Museum of Homelessness'' as part of their Catalyst programme to aid in changing societal opinion in regards to Homeless People especially in the Capital, [[London]]. <ref name = "A Review of Streetfest, the first Homeless Festival in the UK"> {{cite web | author = Paul Atherton | date = 30 September 2018 | title = Museum of Homelessness Blog: Streetfest, A Review | url = http://museumofhomelessness.org/2018/09/17/streetsfest-a-review/}}</ref> Using art, museum objects and campaigning tactics members of the programme will produce a variety of installations around the capital to challenge perceptions to those who find themselves sleeping on buses, in doorways and sofa-surfing.<ref name = "Streets Fest: Hundreds access free services at homeless festival in Finsbury Park"> {{cite web | author = Lucas Cumiskey | date = 11 September 2018 | title = Islington Gazette | url = http://www.islingtongazette.co.uk/news/streets-fest-homeless-event-in-finsbury-park-streets-kitchen-1-5689834}}</ref>
He has one son, Charles Sebastian Atherton-Laurie.<ref name = "Charles Atherton-Laurie: Our London Lives">{{cite video | people = | year = 2016 | title = "Our London Lives" | url = https://www.list.co.uk/event/549625-our-london-lives-recording-a-life/ | format = | medium = film | trans_title = | publisher = Q&D Productions (Not-For-Profit) | location = United Kingdom | accessdate = 19 February 2016 | time = | id = | isbn = | oclc = | quote = | ref =}}</ref>

{{for|the Olympic competitor|Paul Masson (cyclist)}} [[File:Wine label, Paul Masson Champagne Company, Oeil de Perdix.jpg|thumb|350px|Label, Paul Masson Champagne Company, Oeil de Perdix]] '''Paul Masson''' (1859 – 1940) was an early pioneer of [[California]] [[viticulture]] and successful popularizer of Californian [[sparkling wine]].
==Biography== Masson emigrated from the [[Burgundy (region)|Burgundy]] region of [[France]] in 1878 to [[California]], [[United States]], where he met [[Rancho San Juan Bautista|Charles Lefranc]], one of a number of French immigrants who had expanded the [[viticulture]] introduced into the [[Santa Clara Valley]] by the [[Spanish missions in California|Catholic mission]] fathers. Masson went back to France in 1880, but later returned to California due to the depression in the French wine industry caused by the [[phylloxera|Phylloxera plague]]. According to the Paul Masson company web site, in 1892 Masson's first [[sparkling wine]] under the name "[[Champagne (wine)|champagne]]" was introduced at [[Almaden Valley|Almaden]], and Masson eventually became known as the "Champagne King of California". Masson is buried at [[Oak Hill Memorial Park]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]].
==Winery== Masson shifted part of his production to the [[Santa Cruz Mountains]] above [[Saratoga, California]] and built his "chateau" on a knob overlooking the [[Santa Clara Valley]] in 1905. Now known as "The [[Mountain Winery]]", the Paul Masson Mountain Winery is on the [[National Park Service]]'s [[National Register of Historic Places]], though it ceased making wines in 1952. Instead, it serves as a conferencing and events venue - various events are held at the winery, such as concert series, weddings, and other special events. A famous chess tournament was held there annually for a number of years in the late 1970s and early 1980s.<ref>[http://www.cr.nps.gov/nr/travel/santaclara/mas.htm Paul Masson Mountain Winery] National Park Service. Retrieved from on 2004-12-28</ref> Around 2000, the then-current owners of the site hired winemaker Jeffrey Patterson to restart winemaking on site. The vineyards were reestablished at the Mountain Winery in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|title=The History and Legacy of Our Estate|url=http://www.mountainwinery.com/our-wines/estate-wine-history-legacy|website=mountainwinery.com|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
==Advertising== [[File:Orson Welles Paul Masson Tasting party insert.png|350px|right|thumb|[[Orson Welles]] presented a series of distinctive ads for Paul Masson from 1978 to 1981.]] {{Main article|Orson Welles Paul Masson advertisements}} The Paul Masson brand is best remembered for its 1978-1981 marketing association with actor-director [[Orson Welles]], who promised for Masson: "We will sell no wine before its time."<ref name="beethoven">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oSs6DcA6dFI |title=Orson Welles for Paul Masson |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=1980 |website=YouTube |publisher=Darian Glover |access-date=2017-02-12 }}</ref> An infamous, widely circulated and much-parodied outtake for one commercial from the campaign features Welles attempting to deliver his lines while severely inebriated.<ref name="Outtakes1">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VFevH5vP32s |title=Original Takes for Orson Welles Wine Commercial |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=1980 |website=YouTube |publisher=grimscribe126 |access-date=2017-02-12 }}</ref> Welles was eventually fired as a spokesman for the brand in 1981, after answering a question about Paul Masson on a TV chat show, saying that he was now on a diet and so no longer drank wine; he was (briefly) replaced as spokesman by [[Sir John Gielgud]].<ref name="McBride">{{cite book |last=McBride |first=Joseph |date=2006 |title=Whatever Happened to Orson Welles? A Portrait of an Independent Career |location=Lexington, Kentucky |publisher=The University Press of Kentucky |isbn=978-0813124100}}</ref>{{Rp|225}}
Despite the ads' success at the time, the Paul Masson brand has suffered from a long-term image problem, particularly since its founder's death in 1940, in being synonymous with low-end wines. As ''The New York Times'' observed in 1990: "While many consumers know them - who can forget Orson Welles's breathy incantation of 'We will sell no wine before its time' for Masson - they lack cachet."<ref name="TroubledWinery" />
==Paul Masson and NASA== In the 1970s [[NASA]] bought Masson Rare Cream Sherry for a [[Skylab]] mission and packaged some for testing on a [[Reduced gravity aircraft|"zero-G" aircraft]]. Unfortunately, the smell quickly permeated the cabin making astronauts physically sick, and public pressure over taking alcohol into space led NASA to abandon their plans.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/history/oral_histories/BourlandCT/BourlandCT_4-7-06.htm | title= Edited Oral History Transcript - Charles T. Bourland | first=Jennifer | last=Ross-Nazzal | date=7 April 2006 | publisher=NASA Johnson Space Center Oral History Project}}</ref>
==Ownership== The Paul Masson winery and brand were owned for many years by The Seagram Company, Ltd, the global wine and spirits company (along with minority share owners). In the 1980s, Seagram also acquired the Taylor California Cellars brand (and production facilities) from Coca-Cola, based on the premise promoted by then Seagram Strategic Planning head, Mary Cunningham, that the only way to succeed in the wine business was to approach Gallo's massive sales volume. Over the next twenty years, the wine industry would dramatically segment itself with, essentially, all the large volume brands falling by the wayside. Internal competition and resulting cannibalization dramatically reduced the combined sales of Paul Masson and Taylor (as it did with Almaden and Inglenook, also owned by a single parent company).<ref name="TroubledWinery" />
These changes meant that the Paul Masson brand was sold to Vintners International in 1987.<ref name="TroubledWinery">{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEFD81130F931A25756C0A966958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=print|accessdate=2007-11-13|publisher=New York Times|date=12 May 1990|title=A Troubled Winery Where Debt Is Aging|author=Lawrence M. Fisher}}</ref>
Vintners was in turn purchased by the Centera Wine Company (formerly "Canandaigua") of New York in 1993, as part of Vintner's bankruptcy proceedings.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2007-11-13|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CEFD9173CF935A2575AC0A965958260| title=Canandaigua to Acquire Vintners|author=Lawrence M. Fisher|date=16 September 1993}}</ref> Canandaigua was then renamed [[Constellation Brands]] in 2000.
In 2008, Wine Group LLC of San Francisco purchased the Paul Masson winery, which had ceased making wine in 1952, and now serves as a conferencing and events center. Wine Group LLC subsequently removed the Paul Masson name and renamed it "[[Mountain Winery|The Mountain Winery]]". Wine Group LLC also purchased two California wine brands from Constellation Brands, including the Paul Masson table wine range, currently consisting of three types of bottle sold - white, red, and rosé, made from grapes grown elsewhere in California. Meanwhile, Constellation Brands in New York continues to manufacture and sell the profitable Paul Masson brandies.<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2008/02/25/daily50.html Wine Group buys Almaden, Inglenook brands, Paul Masson winery, for $134M] San Francisco Business Times</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Philip Morton Shand''' (21 January 1888 – 30 April 1960), known as '''P. Morton Shand''', was an English journalist, architecture critic (an early proponent of [[modernism]]), wine and food writer, entrepreneur and [[Pomology|pomologist]]. He is also the paternal grandfather of [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]], the second wife of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]].
==Life== {{Refimprove section|date=October 2017}} Shand, the son of the writer and barrister [[Alexander Faulkner Shand]] and his wife Augusta Mary Coates, was born in [[Kensington]], [[London]]. He was educated at [[Eton College]] and [[King's College, Cambridge]], as well as studying at the [[Sorbonne]], Paris, and in [[Heidelberg]], Germany.<ref name="AW">Alan Windsor, ''Letters from Peter Behrens to P. Morton Shand, 1932–1938'', Architectural History, Vol. 37, (1994), pp. 165–187.</ref>
Shand was married four times. His first marriage was to [[Edith Marguerite Harrington]] in April 1916, with whom he had a son, [[Bruce Shand]], father to [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]]. They divorced in 1920.
Shand's second marriage was to Alys Fabre-Tonnerre, in 1920, with whom he had a daughter named Sylvia. They divorced in 1926, his wife having petitioned on the grounds of his adultery.
Shand's third marriage was to Georgette Thérèse Edmée Avril, who he married a month after the divorce decree for his second marriage was granted. They divorced in 1931, without having had any children.
Shand's fourth marriage was to Sybil Mary Sissons (previously Mrs. Slee) in 1931, with whom he had one daughter named [[Elspeth Howe, Baroness Howe of Idlicote|Elspeth]]. Elspeth married [[Geoffrey Howe]], later Baron Howe of Aberavon, who was then a lawyer and later a politician. Elspeth became a life peer in her own right as ''Baroness Howe of Idlicote''. Shand's step-daughter, Mary (Sybil's daughter from her first husband naval Commander John Ambrose Slee) married architect Sir [[James Stirling (architect)|James Stirling]].
Shand died on 30 April 1960 (age 72) in [[Lyon]], France. The poet [[John Betjeman]] and the French wine expert [[André Simon (wine)|André Simon]] wrote addenda to Shand's obituary in ''[[The Times]]''.<ref name="Obit addenda">{{cite news|last1=Betjiman|first1=John|last2=Simon|first2=André L.|authorlink1=John Betjeman|authorlink2=André Simon (wine)|title=Mr. P. Morton Shand|work=The Times|date=6 May 1960|location=London|page=19}}</ref>
==Career==
Shand studied history at King's College, Cambridge, gaining his [[Master of Arts (Oxbridge and Dublin)|MA]] in 1914. Shand served in the First World War with the [[Royal Fusiliers]] regiment,<ref>[http://search.findmypast.co.uk/results/world-records/british-army-service-records-1914-1920?firstname=philip&firstname_variants=true&lastname=shand&yearofbirth=1888&yearofbirth_offset=2 Results for British Army Service Records 1914–1920]</ref> and immediately afterwards, due to his fluent French and German, he was appointed as superintendent of all German prisoners' camps in France.<ref name="Obit addenda"/>
Already in 1914 he had translated from German to English [[Arthur Schnitzler]]'s play ''Liebelei'', under the title ''Playing with Love''. Though his first major publications from that time were on food and wine, he began to also build a reputation as an architecture critic, working in particular for ''Architectural Review'', where he had been influential in steering the journal's then proprietor and sometimes editor Hubert de Cronin Hastings in favour of modernism.<ref>Jonathan Glancey, "Townscape and the AR: Humane urbanism in the 20th century", ''Architectural Review'', 7 June 2013.</ref>
While living in Lyon, France, in the early 1920s, he was invited by the editor of the [[Architectural Association|''Architectural Association Journal'']] to review the [[International Exposition of Modern Industrial and Decorative Arts|Exposition Internationale des Artes Décoratifs]] in Paris of 1925.<ref name="AW" /> In reviewing the exposition, he coined the term "Swedish grace" to describe the Scandinavian design of the time, evident in the work of among others [[Gunnar Asplund]], though by that time a new, modernist architecture and design was emerging, as evident at the exposition in the work of its prime mover [[Le Corbusier]].<ref>Katherine E. Nelson, Raul Cabra, ''New Scandinavian Design'' (2004).</ref><ref>See also [[Nordic Classicism]]</ref>
Shand's first book on architecture, ''Modern Theatres and Cinemas'' was published in 1930 and featured many of those buildings he had encountered in Germany during the late 1920s, arguing that there the cinema had emerged as a separate design typology, not an adaptation of traditional theatre design.
Shand was befriended by some of the leading figures in European modernist architecture, including [[Peter Behrens]], Le Corbusier, head of the [[Bauhaus]] Walter Gropius, Alvar Aalto and Swiss historian-critic [[Sigfried Giedion]], keeping correspondence with each of them. He also developed close links with architects back in the UK, encouraging their participation in the modernist debate. Shand translated from German to English Gropius's 1925 book ''Die neue Architektur und das Bauhaus'', published in 1930 as ''The New Architecture and the Bauhaus''.<ref>[http://www.lib.uea.ac.uk/lib/libinf/find/archives/pritchard/pp29.htm SERIES PP/29<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Shand with furniture designer and entrepreneur [[Jack Pritchard]] helped with Gropius's emigration from Germany to the UK in 1934.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Campbell M |title=What tuberculosis did for modernism: the influence of a curative environment on modernist design and architecture |journal=Med Hist |volume=49 |issue=4 |pages=463–88 |date=October 2005 |pmid=16562331 |pmc=1251640 |doi= 10.1017/s0025727300009169|url=}}, note 34.</ref>
Le Corbusier and Giedion had been prime movers in the foundation of the [[Congrès International d'Architecture Moderne]] (CIAM) in 1928, in the promotion of the cause of modernist architecture and town planning. Giedion was its first and only general secretary. There had been no British participants in the first CIAM conference in 1928. But in January 1929 Shand wrote to Gropius suggesting Howard Robinson, head of the [[Architectural Association]] school of architecture and Shand's own cousin, as the British CIAM representative. When this did not work out, Shand recommended Japan-born, Canada-educated architect [[Wells Coates]]. Shand, together with architects Coates, [[Maxwell Fry]] and [[F. R. S. Yorke]] were the founding members of the [[MARS Group]] (Modern Architectural Research Group), which operated from 1933 to 1937.<ref>[http://www.designmuseum.org/design/the-mars-group The MARS Group / Designing Modern Britain – Design Museum : – Design/Designer Information<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The group came into existence at the prompting of Giedion, after Shand wrote to him.<ref>Eric Paul Mumford, ''The CIAM discourse on urbanism, 1928–1960'' (2000), p. 91.</ref> Shand, Coates, Yorke and three other members of the Mars Group attended their first CIAM congress in 1933, which took place on board an ocean-going liner journeying from Marseilles to Athens in July that year.
A series of articles under the title ''Scenario for a Human Drama'', in ''Architectural Review'' of 1934–5, was Shand's attempt to document and place the contemporary architecture in Europe.<ref>[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-18443458.html Theme: Centenary, 1935–1951. (architecture) – The Architectural Review | Encyclopedia.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In seven parts it set out ideas on the evolution of Continental modernism.<ref>Harry Francis Mallgrave, ''Modern Architectural Theory: A Historical Survey, 1673–1968'' (2005), p. 314.</ref>
Shand was sued for bankruptcy in March 1933, with the court case taking place in August that year.<ref>[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/33913/supplements/1240 London Gazette, Applications for Discharge<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> That same year, however, with Geoffrey Boumphrey, he founded a company Finmar to import Finnish architect [[Alvar Aalto]]'s furniture into the UK,<ref>Kevin Davies, "Finmar and the Furniture of the Future: The Sale of Alvar Aalto’s Plywood Furniture in the UK, 1934–1939", ''Design History'', 1998, 11 (2): 145–156.</ref> for the purposes of which he set up an exhibition of Aalto's furniture and experimental wood reliefs at the [[Fortnum & Mason]] department store in London.<ref>[http://www.studio-international.co.uk/architecture/aalto07.asp Alvar Aalto: Through the Eyes of Shigeru Ban<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1935 he visited Finland with Jack Pritchard and Graham Reid and saw Aalto's [[Paimio Sanatorium]] and the [[Artek (company)|Artek]] furniture factory which made the furniture sold in the UK by Finmar.<ref>[http://www.lib.uea.ac.uk/lib/libinf/find/archives/pritchard/ppchronology.htm Jack Pritchard Chronology<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Despite his early enthusiasm for modernism in design and architecture, by the late 1950s he was far more critical towards the results of modern architecture, writing that: {{quote|text=I have frightful nightmares, and no wonder for I am haunted by a gnawing sense of guilt in having, in however minor and obscure degree, helped to bring about, anyhow encouraged and praised, the embryo searchings that have now materialized into a monster neither of us [Shand or [[Betjeman]]] could have foreseen: Contemporary architecture (= the piling up of gigantic children's toy bricks in utterly dehumanized and meaningless forms), 'Art' and all that. It is no longer funny; it is frightening, all-invading menace.|author=P. Morton Shand (1958)|source=<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=A. N.|authorlink=A. N. Wilson|title=Betjeman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZyC4wEyiTsoC&pg=PA88|accessdate=16 April 2017|date=27 June 2011|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4464-9305-2|page=88}}</ref>}}
Shand demonstrated his knowledge of food and wine in articles and books published during the 1920s. He set out his viewpoint at the beginning of the 300-page ''A Book of Food'' (1927): "This is frankly a book of prejudices, for all food is a question of likes and dislikes. One may be tolerant about religion, politics, and a hundred and one other things, but not about the food that one eats."<ref>Tom Parker Bowles, ''A woman who can't make soup should not be allowed to marry ... Foodie tips from Camilla's outspoken great-grandfather'', ''Daily Mail'', 13 September 2008.</ref>
==Works== *''A Book of French Wines'', 1925. *''A Book of Food'', 1927. *''A Book of Other Wines – Than French'', 1929. *''Bacchus or Wine To-Day and To-Morrow'', 1929. In the series [[To-day and To-morrow]]. *''Modern Theatres and Cinemas'', 1930. *''Building: The Evolution of an Industry'', 1954.
==Translations== *[[Arthur Schnitzler]], ''Playing with Love'' *Walter Gropius, ''The New Architecture and the Bauhaus''
