{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox martial artist | name = Ruqsana Begum | other_names = Warrior Princess | image = | image_size = 220px | alt = | caption = | native_name = রুকসানা বেগম | native_lang = bn | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1983|10|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bethnal Green]], [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets|Tower Hamlets]], [[London]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = [[Gants Hill]], [[Ilford]], [[Essex]], [[England]] | nationality = {{flagicon|ENG}} [[England|English]] | height = {{height|ft=5|in=3}} | weight = {{convert|48|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | weight_class = Atomweight | reach = | style = [[Muay Thai]] [[kickboxing]] | stance = [[Orthodox stance|Orthodox]] | fighting_out_of = [[Bethnal Green]], [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets|Tower Hamlets]], [[London]], [[England]] | team = British Muay Thai Team | teacher = | trainer = Bill Judd | rank = | wrestling = | years_active = 2008–present | kickbox_win = | kickbox_kowin = | kickbox_loss = | kickbox_koloss = | kickbox_draw = | kickbox_nc = | am_win = | am_kowin = | am_loss = | am_koloss = | am_draw = | am_nc = | occupation = [[Kickboxing|Kickboxer]], [[School science technician|Science technician]] | university = [[University of Westminster]] | spouse = {{marriage|Sayed Chowdhury|2006|2008|reason=divorced}} | children = | relatives = | students = | club = KO Gym | school = | url = {{URL|http://www.ruqsana-begum.com/}} | boxrec = | sherdog = | footnotes = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = | updated = }}
'''Ruqsana Begum''' ({{lang-bn|রুকসানা বেগম}}; born 15 October 1983) is an [[England|English]] [[professional]] [[Kickboxing|kickboxer]] and [[Boxing|boxer]]. She is the current British and [[World Kickboxing Association]] female Atomweight (48–50 kg) [[Muay Thai]] boxing champion and captain of the British Muay Thai Team. She is the only Muslim woman who is a national champion in her sport. In March 2018, Begum made the switch from professional kickboxing to boxing.
==Early life== Begum was born in [[Bethnal Green]]<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |last=Lennon|first=Patrick|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/british-female-thai-boxing-champion-kept-training-secret-strict/|title=The British female Thai-boxing champion - who kept her training secret from her strict Muslim family|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|date=14 September 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> and was brought up in [[Seven Kings]], [[Ilford]], [[Essex]], [[England]] to a family of [[British Bangladeshi|Bangladeshi]] origin.<ref name="dailystar">{{cite news |last=Lennon|first=Patrick|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/posts/view/182934|title=Ruqsana Begum: Kicking And Dreaming|work= |location=Bangladesh|publisher=''[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]''|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> She comes from a traditional, religious family and grew up in a strict [[Muslim]] household.<ref name="morningstaronline">{{cite news |last=Simmonds|first=Kadeem|url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-e776-I-am-not-someone-who-likes-conflict,-even-though-I-fight#.VcU3HfktXF8|title=‘I am not someone who likes conflict, even though I fight’|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Morning Star (British newspaper)|Morning Star]]''|date=24 July 2015|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> Begum has said she "grew up caught between two cultures - my traditional culture and values and education and travel and sport."<ref name="thesun">{{cite news |last=Downes Jr|first=Wally|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/3548015/ruqsana-begum-muslim-muay-thai-world-champion-kick-boxing/|title=KICK BOX-OFFICE Ruqsana Begum trained in secret to avoid offending her Muslim family, became kickboxing world champion and is now hot property in Hollywood|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''|date=15 May 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
Begum's paternal grandfather moved to the [[United Kingdom]] from [[Sylhet]], [[Bangladesh]], to fight for the British in the [[World War II|Second World War]].<ref name="dailystar"/> Her father, Awlad,<ref name="thesun"/> worked as a tailor-cum-machinist in a factory making leather jackets for high street fashion stores<ref name="dailystar"/> and her mother, Minara,<ref name="thesun"/> was a housewife. The family lived in a council flat among the predominantly Bangladeshi community.<ref name="telegraph"/> She is the second eldest of four children and lives at home with her family.<ref name="dailystar"/>
Begum went to the local primary school and then to [[Swanlea School]]. She studied [[GCE Advanced Level|A-levels]] in art, history, Bengali, media studies.<ref name="telegraph"/> After studying at UzSWLU in [[Tashkent]], [[Uzbekistan]], in 2006, Begum graduated with a degree in Architecture from the [[University of Westminster]]. She was a trainee [[architect]] and was made redundant after the company she worked for made cuts.<ref name="ilfordrecorder1">{{cite news |last=Munford|first=Colin|url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/sport/ruqsana_gets_her_kicks_from_sport_1_749443|title=Ruqsana gets her kicks from sport|work= |location=Iford|publisher=''[[Ilford Recorder]]''|date=9 December 2010|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> She is a part-qualified architect.<ref name="ilfordrecorder2">{{cite news |last=Richards|first=Joshua|url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/sport/euro_thai_boxing_champion_ruqsana_begum_suffering_from_lack_of_funding_1_991195|title=Euro Thai-boxing champion Ruqsana Begum suffering from lack of funding|work= |location=Ilford|publisher=''[[Ilford Recorder]]''|date=11 August 2011|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="thedailystar">{{cite news |last=Ahmed Ully|first=Ansar|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=250326|title=Kick-boxer Ruqsana wins bronze|work= |location=London|publisher=''[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]]''|date=19 September 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
As a child, Begum played football, badminton and swimming. Since the age of five or six she has been fascinated by martial arts<ref name="bbc3">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p050s65j|title=Ruqsana Begum - Defying sterotypes|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC World Service]]''|date=21 April 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="highsnobiety">{{cite news |last=Pearson|first=Daniel|url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/ruqsana-begum-kickboxer-interview/|title=The Female Muslim Kickboxing Champion Who Was Designing Sport Hijabs Before Nike|work= |location= |publisher=''Highsnobiety''|date=8 March 2018|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> and was inspired by [[Muhammad Ali]] and [[Bruce Lee]].<ref name="morningstaronline"/>
==Professional kickboxing career== In 2002, at the age of 18, Begum took up a kickboxing class after college.<ref name="muslimnews">{{cite news|last=Buara|first=Elham Asaad|url=http://www.muslimnews.co.uk/paper/index.php?article=5860|title=In conversation with…Ruqsana Begum|work=|location=|publisher=''[[The Muslim News]]''|date=29 June 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421021914/http://www.muslimnews.co.uk/paper/index.php?article=5860#|archive-date=21 April 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She initially did it as a hobby in secret due to concerns that her family may not approve.<ref name="easterneye">{{cite news|last=Flaig|first=Maximilian|url=http://www.easterneye.eu/news.html?groupId=8&newsId=1299|title=Interview with kickboxing champ Ruqsana Begum|work=|location=|publisher=''[[India Weekly]]''|date=19 February 2013|accessdate=1 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102194344/http://www.easterneye.eu/news.html?groupId=8&newsId=1299#|archive-date=2 January 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She got herself a part-time job in a chemist, started university and would train every Sunday.<ref name="thesun"/> In 2006, soon after she graduated from university, she told her family that she was practising Muay Thai,<ref name="supportthroughsport">{{cite web|url=http://www.supportthroughsport.co.uk/ruqsanabegum|title=Ruqsana Begum|publisher=''Support through Sport UK''|year=2011|accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref> after she had kept it a secret from her family for almost five years.<ref name="morningstaronline"/> however, after they saw the gym and they didn't try to stop Begum.<ref name="thesun"/> In 2008, she started fighting professionally.<ref name="dailystar"/><ref name="ilfordrecorder1"/>
In 2009, Begum defeated a Malaysian opponent to win a bronze medal at the World Amateur Kickboxing Championship in [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]].<ref name="ilfordrecorder1"/>
On 27 November 2010, in her first final, Begum defeated Paige Farrington to win the British Muay Thai Atomweight Kickboxing Championship Professional title from the Duel at the Dome contest in [[Doncaster]].<ref name="ilfordrecorder1"/><ref name="thedailystar"/> Begum is the only Muslim woman who is a national champion in her sport.<ref name="sky">{{cite news |last=Kelso|first=Paul|url=http://news.sky.com/video/1547749/kickboxer-defying-stereotypes|title=Video: Meet The Athlete Defying Stereotypes|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky News]]''|date=6 September 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
On 31 July 2011, Begum won a gold medal at the European Club Cup Amateur Muay Thai Championship in [[Latvia]].<ref name="ilfordrecorder2"/> She beat a Finnish fighter to secure her place in the final and beat a Turkish fighter in the final to be awarded gold.<ref name="muaythai">{{cite web |url=http://ko-muaythai.com/news/33-muay-thai/figths/201-ruqsana-and-ash-bring-back-medals-at-european-championships.html|title=Ruqsana and Ash bring back medals at European Championships|publisher=''KO Muay Thai''|date=26 September 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
On 6 September 2012, Begum was nominated as British Muay Thai Team Captain and won bronze at the [[International Federation of Muaythai Amateur]] (IFMA) World Championships in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]]. On 9 September 2012, she beat [[Ranini Cundasawmy]] from Mauritius in the quarter-final, before losing her semi-final match, on 11 September 2012, against the European champion, Chyslova Liudmila, from Belarus who proceeded to win silver.<ref name="thedailystar"/><ref name="ilfordrecorder3">{{cite news |last=Richards|first=Joshua|url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/sport/brilliant_begum_bags_bronze_medal_1_1515081|title=Brilliant Begum bags bronze medal|work= |location=Ilford|publisher=''[[Ilford Recorder]]''|date=13 September 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="hamhigh">{{cite news |last=Richards|first=Joshua|url=http://www.hamhigh.co.uk/sport/brilliant_begum_bags_bronze_medal_1_1515081|title=Brilliant Begum bags bronze medal|work= |location=Hampstead and Highgate|publisher=''[[Ham & High]]''|date=13 September 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="london24">{{cite news |last=Richards|first=Joshua|url=http://www.london24.com/sport/other/brilliant_begum_bags_bronze_medal_1_1515081|title=Brilliant Begum bags bronze medal|work= |location=London|publisher=''London24''|date=13 September 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="womensportreport1">{{cite web |url=http://www.womensportreport.com/women-sport_more-gb-success-at-the-muaythai-world-championships_15712|title=More GB Success at the Muaythai World Championships|publisher=''Women Sport Report''|date=4 October 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="womensportreport2">{{cite web |url=http://www.womensportreport.com/features_more-gb-success-at-the-muaythai-world-championships_119|title=More GB Success at the Muaythai World Championships|publisher=''Women Sport Report''|date= |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
On 13 April 2013, Begum fought Silvia La Notte from Italy at the New Bingley Hall in [[Birmingham]] for the International Sport Kickboxing Association (ISKA) World Championship.<ref name="ilfordrecorder4">{{cite news |last=Munford|first=Colin|url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/sport/kickboxer_ruqsana_is_hoping_it_s_home_sweet_home_for_world_title_shot_1_1995321|title=Kickboxer Ruqsana is hoping it’s home sweet home for world title shot|work= |location=Ilford|publisher=''[[Ilford Recorder]]''|date=29 March 2013|accessdate=1 May 2013}}</ref> Although Begum was leading on points, during the fourth round the fight was abandoned after she took a knock to the head.<ref name="broadly.vice">{{cite news |last=Congregalli|first=Matteo|url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/ruqsana-begums-fight-to-be-a-muslim-bangladeshi-thai-boxing-champion|title=Ruqsana Begum's Fight to be a Muslim-Bangladeshi Thai Boxing Champion|work= |location= |publisher=''Broadly''|date=12 September 2013|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
On 14 March 2015, she contested the International Sport Kickboxing Association (ISKA) Women's straw-weight world title fight<ref name="ringevents">{{cite web |url=http://www.ringevents.co.uk/events/ktmma-3/|title=KTMMA 3|publisher=Ring Events|date= |accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> against French national champion, Ludivine Lasnier, at the ILEC Conference Centre in [[Earls Court]], London but lost the title on points.<ref name="broadly.vice"/><ref name="londonlive">{{cite web |url=http://www.londonlive.co.uk/news/2015-03-02/it-s-hard-for-muslim-girls-to-get-into-combat-sports|title=‘It’s hard for Muslim girls to get into combat sports’|publisher=[[London Live (TV channel)|London Live]]|date=2 March 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
On 7 November 2015, she was due to contest the [[World Kickboxing Association]] (WKA) title against Josefine Lindgren Knutsson of Sweden in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], London,<ref name="sky"/> however, after Begum suffered from a viris the fight was postponed<ref name="skysports2">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www1.skysports.com/news/12040/9043713/|title=Kickboxer Ruqsana Begum fights for world title on Saturday|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky Sports News]]''|date=3 November 2015|accessdate=1 December 2015}}</ref> until February 2016 and rescheduled for April 23<ref name="skysports3">{{cite news |last=Trehan|first=Dev|url=http://www.skysports.com/more-sports/other-sports/news/29876/10167683/world-title-contender-ruqsana-begum-fighting-for-coach-and-community|title=World title contender Ruqsana Begum fighting for coach and community|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky Sports News]]''|date=14 February 2016|accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> against Susanna Salmijärvi<ref name="skysports4">{{cite news |last=Trehan|first=Dev|url=http://www.skysports.com/more-sports/other-sports/news/29876/10252350/kickboxer-ruqsana-begum-thinks-world-title-win-can-be-a-game-changer|title=Kickboxer Ruqsana Begum thinks world title win can be a game-changer|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky Sports News]]''|date=21 April 2016|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref> which she contested and won.<ref name="thetimes">{{cite news |last=Broadbent|first=Rick|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/muslim-fighter-with-me-who-left-an-arranged-marriage-to-win-world-title-svxhhzt57|title=Muslim fighter with ME who left an arranged marriage to win world title|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=2 December 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
Begum trains under Bill Judd,<ref name="ilfordrecorder2"/><ref name="asiana">{{cite news |last=Razzaq|first=Mahvish|url=http://asiana.tv/health/warrior-princess|title=Muay Thai Champion Ruqsana Begum is going for gold|work= |location= |publisher=''Asiana TV''|date=4 September 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> and fights out of the KO Gym in [[Bethnal Green]], [[London]].<ref name="muslimnews"/> She trains six times a week<ref name="instantecare">{{cite news |last=Frue|first=Kiesha|url=https://www.instantecare.co.uk/healthcare/?p=284|title=Exclusive Interview with Ruqsana Begum|work= |location= |publisher=''Instant e–Care''|date=10 June 2015|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> for two hours each day, and during the build-up to a fight she trains twice a day.<ref name="matchesfashion">{{cite news |last=Kemble|first=Harry|url=http://www.matchesfashion.com/womens/the-style-report/2015/08/the-activewear-issue/the-interview-kickboxer-ruqsana-begum-video|title=Seven Kings boxer turns hijab-designer to get Muslim women active|work= |location=Iford|publisher=''[[Ilford Recorder]]''|date=11 June 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> She also does [[yoga]].<ref name="telegraph"/>
She is signed up by RDX Equipment and her main sponsor is DCD Property Company.<ref name="sportspromedia">{{cite news |last=Hutchison|first=Finlay|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/notes_and_insights/end_it_like_begum_a_british_asian_womans_quest_for_the_muay_thai_world_titl|title=End it like Begum: a British Asian woman’s quest for the muay thai world title|work= |location= |publisher=''SportsPro''|date=19 December 2014|accessdate=1 September 2015}}</ref> In September 2016, Begum signed with Shakir Entertainment Management in New York City.
==Professional boxing career== {{Infobox boxer | name = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | realname = | nickname = | weight = [[Super flyweight]] | height = {{height|ft=5|in=3}} | reach = | nationality = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | style = [[Orthodox stance|Orthodox]] | boxrec = 828042 | total = 1 | wins = | KO = | losses = | draws = 1 | no contests = | website = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = | embed = }}
In January 2018, Begum signed a three-year<ref name="worldboxingnews3">{{cite news |last=Hewlett|first=Joe|url=http://www.worldboxingnews.net/2018/03/15/news/exclusive-david-haye-manager-adam-morallee-talks-s-jam-boxing-signing-ruqsana-begum-as-debut-loom|title=Exclusive: Adam Morallee talks S-Jam signing Ruqsana Begum as debut looms|work= |location= |publisher=''World Boxing News''|date=15 March 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> a managerial contract with [[Joe Joyce (boxer)|Joe Joyce]]'s handler Sam Jones<ref name="worldboxingnews1">{{cite news |last=Jay|first=Phil|url=http://www.worldboxingnews.net/2018/01/16/news/exclusive-kickboxing-and-muay-thai-champion-ruqsana-begum-set-for-run-in-pro-ranks|title=Exclusive: Kickboxing and Muay Thai champion Ruqsana Begum set for run in pro ranks|work= |location= |publisher=''World Boxing News''|date=16 January 2018|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> and Adam Morallee who made her their first client since forming the management company S-Jam Boxing with plans to turn professional in boxing.<ref name="worldboxingnews1"/> She also signed with former heavyweight champion [[David Haye]]'s Hayemaker Promotions.<ref name="bbc5">{{cite news |last=Sheikh|first=Rahil|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/boxing/43431693|title=First female British Muslim kickboxing champion inspires a new generation|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=17 March 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
In 17 March, Begum made her professional boxing debut under [[Marquess of Queensberry Rules|Queensberry Rules]] against Bulgaria's Ivanka Ivanova [[York Hall]] in Bethnal Green, London, which was screen on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]],<ref name="news">{{cite news |last=Kidd|first=Dave|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/boxing/british-kickboxing-champions-inspirational-story-takes-another-twist/news-story/339534735011fede8e714c27d942241e|title=British kickboxing champion’s inspirational story takes another twist|work= |location=Australia|publisher=''[[news.com.au]]''|date=15 March 2018|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="nytimes">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/03/16/sports/16reuters-boxing-women-ruqsana-begum.html|title=Begum Ready for Debut After Overcoming Many Obstacles|work= |location=New York|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=16 March 2018|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="geo">{{cite news |last= |first= at Begum delay and draw / Camacho scores TKO|work= |location= |publisher=''World Boxing News''|date=18 March 2018|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
==Other work== On top of her own professional commitments, Begum is a personal trainer and instructor. She also works as an instructor one night a week<ref name="ilfordrecorder2"/> giving free after-school<ref name="dailystar"/><ref name="ilfordrecorder1"/> Muay Thai classes every Monday at the Lions Den Gym in [[Chadwell Heath]], London<ref name="edp241">{{cite news |last=Richards|first=Joshua|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/ilford_s_british_muay_thai_boxing_champion_set_for_02_arena_bout_1_1196553|title=Ilford’s British Muay-Thai boxing champion set for 02 Arena bout|work= |location=Norwich|publisher=''[[Eastern Daily Press]]''|date=3 February 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> for the children in the East End.<ref name="muslimnews"/> She also coaches ladies-only classes every Sunday.<ref name="easterneye"/>
From 2006, she worked at an architectural firm in [[Epping Forest]] but lost the job because of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|recession in 2008]].<ref name="telegraph"/> From 2009, she worked part-time, two days a week, as an unqualified science technician at [[Swanlea School, Business and Enterprise College|Swanlea School]] in [[Whitechapel]], London.<ref name="ilfordrecorder1"/><ref name="ilfordrecorder2"/> She resigned from Swanlea School after frequent absences from work.
She is a boxing and Muay Thai<ref name="supportthroughsport"/> coach for Fight for Peace, a charity which uses boxing as a prevention and rehabilitation model to confront the problem of child and youth participation in crime, gangs and gun violence within disadvantaged communities.<ref name="thedailystar"/><ref name="muslimnews"/><ref name="eastlondonnews">{{cite news |last=Rahman|first=Emdad|url=http://www.eastlondonnews.com/sparring-with-the-atomweight/|title=Sparring with the Atomweight|work= |location=London|publisher=''East London News''|date=21 July 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="fitmenow">{{cite news|last=Walter|first=Glen|url=http://fitmenow.co.uk/exclusive-interview-ruqsana-begum-british-muay-thai-champion/|title=EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: Ruqsana Begum – British Muay Thai Champion|work=|location=|publisher=''FitMeNow''|date=10 October 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102191726/http://fitmenow.co.uk/exclusive-interview-ruqsana-begum-british-muay-thai-champion/#|archive-date=2 January 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She is an ambassador for Sporting Equals, a charity who help people from ethnic minorities to access sport, whoever you are and at all levels.<ref name="skysports1">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www1.skysports.com/news/12040/9043713/|title=British Muay Thai Boxing champion Ruqsana Begum positive on change|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky Sports News]]''|date=26 November 2013|accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="desiblitz2">{{cite news |last=Farooq|first=Aisha|url=http://www.desiblitz.com/content/top-asian-women-in-sport|title=Top Asian Women in Sport|work= |location= |publisher=''DESIblitz''|date=6 June 2015|accessdate=1 July 2015}}</ref>
In 2015, Begum created a sports [[hijab]] for non-athletes for combat fighting sports and to help more Muslim women get into combat sports.<ref name="independent">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/video/?videoid=4088051135001|title=East End boxing champion launches sports hijab|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=24 February 2015|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="wharf2">{{cite news |last=Bishop|first=Rachel|url=http://www.wharf.co.uk/news/business/east-end-boxing-champion-launches-8709050|title=British Muay Thai champion has eyes set on world domination|work= |location=London|publisher=''[[The Wharf (newspaper)|The Wharf]]''|date=2 March 2015|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref> She was first inspired to create the product when she saw sprinter [[Ruqaya Al-Ghasra]] struggle to wear a headscarf at the [[Athletics at the 2006 Asian Games|2006 Asian Games]].<ref name="standard">{{cite news |last=Alwakeel|first=Ramzy|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/thai-boxing-champion-designs-sports-hijab-to-encourage-muslim-schoolgirls-to-get-active-10315723.html|title=Thai boxing champion designs 'sports hijab' to encourage Muslim schoolgirls to get active|work= |location=London|publisher=''[[London Evening Standard]]''|date=16 June 2015|accessdate=1 July 2015}}</ref> She thought up the idea during the [[2012 Summer Olympics|London 2012 Olympics]] when she learnt of an American athlete who was told her Islamic headscarf did not meet health and safety requirements.<ref name="ilfordrecorder5">{{cite news |last=Kemble|first=Harry|url=http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/news/seven_kings_boxer_turns_hijab_designer_to_get_muslim_women_active_1_4109170|title=Seven Kings boxer turns hijab-designer to get Muslim women active|work= |location=Iford|publisher=''[[Ilford Recorder]]''|date=11 June 2015|accessdate=1 July 2015}}</ref> The hijab is a fitted, breathable version of the traditional scarf worn to conceal Muslim women's hair and chests.<ref name="standard"/> It uses a breathable fabrics which is designed to fit comfortably around the head.<ref name="ilfordrecorder5"/> In April 2016, she launched her own line of sports hijabs. Begum designed her own line and outsourced manufacturing to a factory in Pakistan, after trying unsuccessfully to line up a manufacturer in England.<ref name="money.cnn">{{cite news |last=Smith|first=Aaron|url=http://www.money.cnn.com/2016/04/09/smallbusiness/sports-hijab-muslim-muay-thai/|title=Muslim muay Thai fighter launches her own line of sports hijabs|work= |location= |publisher=''[[CNNMoney]]''|date=9 April 2016|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="localsyr">{{cite news |last=Smith|first=Aaron|url=http://www.localsyr.com/news/muay-thai-fighter-launches-her-own-line-of-sports-hijabs|title=Muslim muay Thai fighter launches her own line of sports hijabs|work= |location= |publisher=''Local SYR''|date=9 April 2016|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="elle">{{cite news |last=Rodulfo|first=Kristina|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/news/a35649/ruqsana-begum-sports-hijabs/|title=This Badass Kickboxing Champion Is Launching a Line of Sports Hijabs|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]''|date=15 April 2016|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref>
==Media appearances== In June 2011, Begum was interviewed by Anwarul Hoque on [[BBC Asian Network]].<ref name="bbcasiannetwork">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00xcfk3|title=Kickboxer Ruqsana Begum|publisher=[[BBC Asian Network]]|date=9 June 2011|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> In August 2014, she was interviewed by Sunny and Shay Grewal on [[BBC London 94.9]].<ref name="bbclondon">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01gwclm|title=Kickboxer Ruqsana Begum|publisher=[[BBC London 94.9]]|date=3 August 2014|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> In March 2015, she was interviewed by [[London Live (TV channel)|London Live]].<ref name="londonlive"/> In September of the same year, she was interviewed by [[Sky News]].<ref name="sky"/>
In April 2016, Begum starred in [[Selfridges]] advert ''Incredible Machines'' to celebrate body confidence.<ref name="dailymail">{{cite news |last=Hodgkin|first=Emily|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-3553870/Female-boxing-champion-trans-woman-plus-size-model-strip-underwear-celebrate-body-confidence.html|title='I feel powerful like a Ferrari': Female boxing champion, a trans woman and a plus-size model strip to their underwear to celebrate body confidence|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Mail Online]]''|date=25 April 2016|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref> In February 2017, she featured in a 30-second [[Adidas]] advert which tells the stories of 15 women athletes and builds on the brand's marketing around defying convention titled 'Unleash Your Creativity'.<ref name="thedrum">{{cite news |last=Connelly|first=Tony|url=http://www.thedrum.com/news/2017/02/02/adidas-tells-the-stories-female-athletes-struggles-with-unleash-your-creativity|title=Adidas tells the stories of female athletes' struggles with 'Unleash Your Creativity' campaign|work= |location= |publisher=''The Drum''|date=2 February 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
In April 2017, Begum was interviewed by ''Sportshour'' on ''[[BBC World Service]]''.<ref name="bbc3"/> In June, she was interviewed by ''[[BBC Three]]''<ref name="bbc4">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcthree/item/470bb480-4714-495b-8522-ae5b854b35b1|title=Fight Like A Girl: Ruqsana Begum hid her trophies from her family for five years|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=23 June 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> for the "Like A Girl Can" campaign.<ref name="metro">{{cite news |last=Lawrence|first=Hannah|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/2017/06/24/incredible-world-champion-muay-thai-kickboxer-kept-her-sport-and-trophies-secret-from-her-family-for-five-years-6731805/|title=The British female Thai-boxing champion - who kept her training secret from her strict Muslim family|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''|date=24 June 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
In March 2018, [[David Leon]] was enlisted by [[Nowness]] to make a short documentary called ''Endurance Test: Ruqsana Begum'' about how Begum rose to the top of her field.<ref name="versus">{{cite news |last=Davey|first=Jacob|url=https://www.versus.uk.com/2018/03/watch-female-british-bangladeshi-kickboxing-champion-ruqsana-begum-action/|title=Watch Female British-Bangladeshi Kickboxing Champion Ruqsana Begum in Action|work= |location= |publisher=''Versus''|date=8 March 2018|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== In May 2012, Begum was shortlisted for the Muslim Women's in Sport Foundation Ambassador Awards for the United Kingdom Sportswoman of the Year award held at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref name="mwsf">{{cite web |url=http://awards.mwsf.org.uk/shortlist.html|title=Shortlist|publisher=''Muslim Women's Sport Foundation''|date= |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="kickitout">{{cite web |url=http://www.kickitout.org/news.php/news_id/5444|title=(UK) MWSF announce Ambassador Awards shortlist|publisher=''Kick It Out''|date=13 April 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="thefa">{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/WhatWeDo/Equality/NewsAndFeatures/2012/muslim-womens-sports-foundation-award|title=Muslim Women's awards|publisher=''The FA''|date=2 May 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="sportsister">{{cite news |last=Patel|first=Holly|url=http://www.sportsister.com/2012/04/11/awards-first-ambassador-awards-night-for-muslim-women/|title=Awards: First Ambassador Awards night for Muslim women|work= |location= |publisher=''Sport Sister''|date=11 April 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="theasianworld">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.theasianworld.co.uk/index.php/shortlist-announced/|title=Shorlist Announced|work= |location= |publisher=''The Asian World''|date=15 May 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
In January 2012, she was named in the ''[[British Bangladeshi Power 100]]'' for her work in education, culture and sports.<ref name="edp242">{{cite news |last=Sam-Daliri|first=Nadia|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/east_end_bangladeshis_reach_power_100_list_1_1188767|title=East End Bangladeshis reach "Power 100" list|work= |location=Norwich|publisher=''[[Eastern Daily Press]]''|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="bbpower100">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://bbpower100.com/spotlight-of-the-week-ruqsana-begum/|title=British Atomweight Muay-Thai boxing champion – Ruqsana Begum|work= |location= |publisher=British Bangladeshi Power 100|date=9 March 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> In February 2012, she won a special achievement award at the [[Canary Wharf]] Sports Awards.<ref name="whufc">{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120218/obrien-gives-back_2236884_2613583|title=O'Brien gives back |publisher=''West Ham United''|date=18 February 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="wharf1">{{cite news |last=Hayes|first=Simon|url=http://www.wharf.co.uk/2012/02/table-tennis-star-ashley-wins.html|title=Table tennis star Ashley wins Canary Wharf award|work= |location=London|publisher=''Wharf''|date=3 February 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
In September 2013, Begum was awarded Sports Personality of the Year at the Asian Achievers Awards.<ref name="abplgroup">{{cite web |url=http://aaa.abplgroup.com/previous-winners/2013|title=Asian Achievers Award 2013|publisher=Asian Achievers Award 2013|date= |accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="desiblitz1">{{cite news |last=Pandit|first=Vishal|url=http://www.desiblitz.com/content/asian-achievers-awards-2013-highlights|title=The Asian Achievers Awards 2013 Highlights|work= |location= |publisher=''DESIblitz''|date=16 September 2013|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> In March 2017, she was awarded the UK Sport Inspirational Performance of the Year award at the [[Lycamobile]] British Ethnic Diversity Sports Awards (BEDSAs) held at the [[London Hilton on Park Lane]].<ref name="voice-online">{{cite news |last=Hinds|first=Rodney|url=http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/british-ethnic-diversity-sports-awards-honoured-sir-mo|title=British Ethnic Diversity Sports Awards honoured Sir Mo|work= |location= |publisher=''Voice Online''|date=23 March 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="skysports6">{{cite news |last=Trehan|first=Dev|url=http://www.skysports.com/more-sports/other-sports/news/29877/10807310/sir-mo-farah-and-kadeena-cox-honoured-at-bedsas|title=Sir Mo Farah and Kadeena Cox honoured at BEDSAs|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky Sports News]]''|date=19 March 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="skysports5">{{cite news |last=Trehan|first=Dev|url=http://www.skysports.com/boxing/news/12183/10791729/katie-taylor-now-has-platform-to-demonstrate-what-she-stands-for-says-ruqsana-begum|title=Katie Taylor now has platform to demonstrate what she stands for, says Ruqsana Begum|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Sky Sports News]]''|date=7 March 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
In October 2016, Begum was named one of the "Young British Muslim Millennials Changing The World" by ''[[The Asian Today]]''. <ref name="theasiantoday">{{cite news |last=Ramchurn|first=Sheena|url=http://www.theasiantoday.com/index.php/2016/10/11/tere-naal-ishqa-depicts-emotional-quotient-shivaay/|title=GENERATION M: Young British Muslims Millenials Changing the World|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Asian Today]]''|date=11 October 2016|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Begum is a [[Muslim]]<ref name="dailystar"/><ref name="skysports1"/><ref name="bbc2">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01gwclm|title=Kickboxer Ruqsana Begum|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC London 94.9]]''|date=17 September 2013|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> and does not drink alcohol.<ref name="instantecare"/> She is 5 feet 3 inches tall.<ref name="thesundaytimes">{{cite news |last=Myers|first=Rebecca|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/sport/boxing/article1606002.ece|title=Meet the ‘little princess’ who broke her coach’s ribs|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Sunday Times]]''|date=13 September 2015|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref> Begum suffers from [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], also known as myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME),<ref name="skysports4"/> which she was diagnosed after she won the British title in 2010. Begum has had to adapt her training to accommodate her condition<ref name="thesun"/> with a strict diet and training regime.<ref name="bbc5"/><ref name="dhakatribune">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/sport/other-sports/2017/06/24/bangladeshi-brit-kickboxing-champion/|title=Breaking stereotypes: The Bangladeshi-Brit world kickboxing champion|work= |location=Dhaka|publisher=''[[Dhaka Tribune]]''|date=24 June 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref>
In 2006, at the age of 22,<ref name="telegraph"/> Begum's parents [[arranged marriage|arranged her marriage]] to, Sayed Chowdhury, a banker from [[Barking, London|Barking]]. She moved in with her husband and his parents.<ref name="thetimes"/> Her father-in-law was on dialysis and Begum had to juggle healthcare with household duties and her career as an unqualified architect.<ref name="thetimes"/> Eight months later,<ref name="telegraph"/> after collapsing one morning,<ref name="thetimes"/> she spent two days in hospital and was later diagnosed as suffering from severe panic attacks. She moved back home to her parent's house<ref name="telegraph"/> and spent months in bed<ref name="thetimes"/> recuperating<ref name="telegraph"/> In 2008, husband then filed for divorce.<ref name="telegraph"/> She has since moved into her own flat in [[Gants Hill]], Ilford, but still spends half the week with her parents, who live nearby.<ref name="telegraph"/>
In March 2012, Begum met [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] at [[Walthamstow]] Town Hall, during the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Queen's Diamond Jubilee]] tour of the UK.<ref name="bbc1">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-17546295|title=Diamond Jubilee: Queen visits three London boroughs|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=29 March 2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="The Queen's Diamond Jubilee Year">{{cite book |last=Bullen|first=Annie|title=The Queen's Diamond Jubilee Year: A Royal Souvenir|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rii15cfJghwC&pg=PA48&dq=Ruqsana+Begum&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAGoVChMIv9SEr4GNxgIVCgfbCh0VeQDZ#v=onepage&q=Ruqsana%20Begum&f=false|year=2012|publisher=[[The History Press]]|page=48|isbn=978-1841654096}}</ref> She was selected to be an [[2012 Summer Olympics|Olympic]] torchbearer in recognition of her sporting achievements and community work, helping young people to engage in sports and giving them a focus in life<ref name="muslimnews"/> in the East London community.<ref name="london2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.london2012.com/torch-relay/torchbearers/torchbearers=ruqsana-begum-5336/index.html|title=Ruqsana Begum|publisher=''London 20120''|date= |accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> On 21 July 2012, she carried the [[Olympic flame|Olympic Torch]] in [[Greenwich]], London.<ref name="greenwich">{{cite web |url=http://www.greenwich-2012.com/info/9/entertainment_and_tourism/56/olympic_torch_relay_through_royal_greenwich/2|title=Olympic Torch Relay through Royal Greenwich|publisher=''Royal Borough of Greenwich''|year=2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="royalgreenwich">{{cite web |url=http://www.royalgreenwich.gov.uk/info/200131/greenwich_2012_community/1170/torch_relay_through_royal_greenwich/3|title=Torch Relay through Royal Greenwich|publisher=''Royal Borough of Greenwich''|year=2012|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref>
In March 2016, Begum revealed her coach, Bill Judd, is terminally ill with cancer.<ref name="skysports3"/>
In 2017, Begum went on a pilgrimage to [[Mecca]], [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name="telegraph"/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} '''Snehansu Kanta Acharya,''' Bar at Law (1 September 1913 – 27 August 1986) was a former Advocate General (1977-1986) of [[West Bengal]], [[India]] and a [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] leader.
==Background and education== He was the son of the Sashi Kanta Acharya Chaudhuri, a former [[Maharaja]] of [[Mymensingh]], a premier [[zamindar]] in Bengal. The Maharajas of Mymensingh were the wealthiest and senior most zamindars of the district of Mymensingh and ranked high in the order of precedence in the Government House in Calcutta. Mymensingh was the predecessor estate of most other ''zamindaris'' of the district. He studied at [[Scottish Church College]],<ref>''Some Alumni of Scottish Church College'' in ''175th Year Commemoration Volume''. Scottish Church College, April 2008. page 593</ref> and later at the [[University of Calcutta]]. He was called to the Bar by the Honourable Society of the Middle Temple in London.
==Family== His wife, Supriya Acharya (Mukhopadhyaya), daughter of Bengali writer [[Sourindra Mohan Mukhopadhyaya]] was also an active member of [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]].<ref>http://pd.cpim.org/2002/nov17/11172002_bengal_supriya.htmObituary of Supriya Acharya {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207192156/http://pd.cpim.org/2002/nov17/11172002_bengal_supriya.htm |date=7 February 2009 }}</ref> His son, Sourangshu Kanta Acharya, is a doctor and his daughter, Bijoya Goswami, is a Sanskrit scholar. Famous singer [[Suchitra Mitra]] was his sister-in law.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Sansad Bangali charitavidhan|language=Bangla|editor=Anjali Basu|volume=2|publisher=Sahitya Sansad|year=1998|isbn=8185626650|location=Kolkata|page=400}}</ref>
==Political career== He was a member of the Indian Students Group Movement, during the freedom struggle. This movement was formed in support of Socialist (Marxist) ideology, to protest against colonial rule of India and to counteract fascism. He worked as rescue volunteer in the time of 1946 riot in [[Kolkata]] before joining the [[Communist Party of India]]. He was closely associated with the former chief minister of West Bengal, [[Shri]] [[Jyoti Basu]]. He had received the First Order of Merit of Syria in 1957 and had led several delegations to Europe, Asia and Africa.<ref name=":0" />
== Memoirs == A law college, [[Snahanshu Kanta Acharya Institute of Law]] (SKAIL) was established in his name under [[University of Kalyani]]. It is situated in the university campus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://skail.org/|title=SNEHANGSHU KANTA ACHARYA INSTITUTE OF LAW|last=|first=|date=|website=skail.org|access-date=7 March 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Muktagachha Upazila#Former Major Zamindars of Mymensingh|Major Zamindars of Mymensingh]]

Page 158] * [http://www.hinduonnet.com/2000/05/06/stories/02060008.htm "Jail Diary"]

{{for|the U.S. federal judge|William Hercules Hays}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Will Hays |image = Will-H-Hays.jpg |office = Chairman of the [[Motion Picture Association of America|Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America]] |term_start = 1922 |term_end = 1945 |predecessor = Position established |successor = [[Eric Johnston]] |office1 = 46th [[United States Postmaster General]] |president1 = [[Warren G. Harding]] |term_start1 = March 5, 1921 |term_end1 = March 3, 1922 |predecessor1 = [[Albert S. Burleson]] |successor1 = [[Hubert Work]] |office2 = Chairman of the [[Republican National Committee]] |term_start2 = 1918 |term_end2 = 1921 |predecessor2 = [[William Russell Willcox]] |successor2 = [[John T. Adams]] |birth_name = William Harrison Hays |birth_date = {{birth date|1879|11|5}} |birth_place = [[Sullivan, Indiana]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|1954|3|7|1879|11|5}} |death_place = [[Sullivan, Indiana]], U.S. |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Jessie Herron |education = [[Wabash College]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} }} '''William Harrison Hays Sr.''' ({{IPAc-en|h|eɪ|z}}; November 5, 1879 – March 7, 1954) was a United States politician, chairman of the [[Republican National Committee]] (1918–21), [[U.S. Postmaster General]] (1921–22), and, from 1922–1945, the first chairman of the [[Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America]] (MPPDA). He became the namesake of the 1930 [[United States Motion Picture Production Code of 1930|Motion Picture Production Code]], informally (and inaccurately) referred to as the Hays Code, which spelled out a set of moral guidelines for the self-censorship of content in [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood cinema]].<ref name=obit/>
==Biography== Hays was born in [[Sullivan, Indiana]], on November 5, 1879, and attended [[Wabash College]] in [[Crawfordsville, Indiana]]. He was the [[campaign manager|manager]] of [[Warren G. Harding]]'s successful campaign for the [[President of the United States|Presidency of the United States]] in the [[U.S. presidential election, 1920|1920 election]] and was subsequently appointed Postmaster General. While serving in the Harding Administration, he became peripherally involved in the [[Teapot Dome scandal]].
==Teapot Dome scandal==
Oilman [[Harry Ford Sinclair]] devised a scheme in which twenty-five cents was diverted from the sale of every barrel of oil sold from the oil field leases that were the focus of the [[Teapot Dome scandal]]. Sinclair testified that he "loaned" Will H. Hays, then-chairman of the Republican National Committee, $185,000 worth of [[Liberty Bonds]], later getting back $100,000. Sinclair also gave Hays $75,000 as an outright gift to the Committee. At the time, Hays was attempting to pay off the 1920 Republican campaign debt. Hays later approached a number of wealthy men and told them that if they would contribute to pay down the Committee's debt, he would reimburse them for their contributions with Liberty Bonds.
In 1924, after his resignation from the Harding administration, and while he was serving as President of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Hays was called to testify before the Senate Committee on Public Lands. When asked how much money Sinclair had contributed to the Republican Party, Hays testified that his contribution was $75,000. In 1928, after more details of Sinclair's scheme had emerged, Hays was called to testify again. Hays then told the full story of Sinclair's contribution, including the donation of $185,000 in Liberty Bonds and the $75,000 cash contribution. He stated that he had not mentioned the bonds in his earlier testimony because the Committee "had not asked about any bonds." While there was some public perception that Hays was attempting to conceal Sinclair's large contribution to the Republican National Committee, he testified that he was "using the bonds to raise money for the deficit." <ref>Frederick Lewis Allen (1959). ''Only Yesterday: An Informal History of the 1920's,'' New York: Harper & Row.</ref>
==MPPDA Chairman== Hays resigned his cabinet position on January 14, 1922, to become Chairman of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America (MPPDA) shortly after the organization's founding.<ref>"Hays to Be Mogul in Silver Screen Realm", ''San Antonio Express'', January 15, 1922, p 4</ref> He began his new job, at a $35,360 <!--$35,360 is $17 per hour NOT $100,000--> annual salary ({{Inflation|US|35360|1922|r=-4|fmt=eq}}), on March 6 of that year.<ref>"Will Hays, Who Is to Get $17 Hourly, to Make the Movies Behave Hereafter", ''Syracuse Herald'', March 5, 1922, p33</ref> There was speculation that he would be paid between $100,000 and $150,000 a year.<ref name=landis>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |quote=Postmaster General Will H. Hays yesterday signed a contract to become the "Landis of the movies" for three years, beginning next March 4 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9806E6DD1130EE3ABC4152DFB7668389639EDE |title=Will H. Hays Signs To Direct Movies. Will Formally Resign From the Cabinet Today, to Take Effect on March 4. To Form New Association. His Signature Is Placed on Contract After Telephone Talk With the President |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=January 19, 1922 |accessdate=January 12, 2015 }}</ref>
The goal of the organization was to renovate the image of the movie industry in the wake of the scandal surrounding the alleged rape and murder of model and actress [[Virginia Rappe]], of which film star [[Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle]] was accused, and amid growing calls by religious groups for federal censorship of the movies. Hiring Hays to "clean up the pictures" was, at least in part, a public relations ploy and much was made of his conservative credentials, including his roles as a Presbyterian deacon and past chairman of the Republican Party.
In his new position in Hollywood, Hays' main roles were to persuade individual state censor boards not to ban specific films outright and to reduce the financial impact of the boards' cuts and edits. At that time, the studios were required by state laws to pay the censor boards for each foot of film excised and for each title card edited; in addition, studios also had the expense of duplicating and distributing separate versions of each censored film for the state or states that adhered to a particular board's decisions. [[Image:HungerfordCartoon.jpg|thumb|300px|1922 [[editorial cartoon]] by [[Cyrus Cotton "Cy" Hungerford|Cy Hungerford]] illustrating the perception that Hays was coming to rescue the movie industry.]]
Hays attempted to reduce studio costs (and improve the industry's image in general) by advising individual studios on how to produce movies to reduce the likelihood that the film would be cut. Each board kept its "standards" secret (if, indeed, they had any standardization at all), so Hays was forced to intuit what would or would not be permitted by each board. At first he applied what he called "The Formula" but it was not particularly successful; from that he developed a set of guidelines he called "The Don'ts and Be Carefuls". In general his efforts at pre-release self-censorship were unsuccessful in quieting calls for federal censorship.
Catholic bishops and lay people tended to be leery of federal censorship and favored the Hays approach of self-censorship; these included the outspoken Catholic layman [[Martin J. Quigley]], publisher of ''Exhibitors Herald-World'' (a trade magazine for independent exhibitors). For several months in 1929, Martin Quigley, [[Joseph Breen]], Father [[Daniel A. Lord]] S.J., Father FitzGeorge Dinneen S.J., and Father Wilfred Parsons (editor of Catholic publication ''America'') discussed the desirability of a new and more stringent code of behavior for the movies. With the blessing of [[George Mundelein|Cardinal George W. Mundelein]] of Chicago, Father Lord authored the code, which later became known as "The [[Production Code]]", "The Code", and "The Hays Code". It was presented to Will Hays in 1930 who said, "My eyes nearly popped out when I read it. This was the very thing I had been looking for".
The studio heads were less enthusiastic but they agreed to make The Code the rule of the industry, albeit with many loopholes that allowed studio producers to override the Hays Office's application of it. From 1930 to 1934, the Production Code was only slightly effective in fighting back calls for federal censorship. However, things came to a head in 1934 with widespread threats of Catholic boycotts of "immoral" movies, as well as reduced funding from Catholic financiers such as [[A. P. Giannini]] of the [[Bank of America]]. As a result, the studios granted MPPDA full authority to enforce the Production Code on all studios, creating a relatively strict regime of self-censorship which endured for decades. (The Code was set aside in the 1960s when the MPAA adopted the age-based rating system in force today.) Also in 1934, to deal with "inappropriate" industry personnel, alongside the Code's concern with the industry's output, Hays created a list of 117 names of performers whose personal lives he thought made them unfit to appear in films.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Russo|first1=Vito|title=The Celluloid Closet: Homosexuality in the Movies |date=1987|publisher=Harper & Row|location=NY|page=45|edition=Revised}}</ref>
Hays' philosophy might best be summed up by a statement he reportedly made to a movie director: "When you make a woman cross her legs in the films, maybe you don't need to see how she can cross them and stay within the law; but how low she can cross them and still be interesting".<ref>''Current Biography 1943,'' p277</ref>
Hays faced much international pressure to block film scripts and scenes offensive to foreign nations. Many European nations imposed quotas designed to boost domestic productions over Hollywood imports. A key accomplishment of Hays was his work with the U.S. government, particularly the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] and the [[United States Department of Commerce|Department of Commerce]], in maintaining Hollywood's domination of overseas movie markets.<ref>John Trumpbour (2002). ''Selling Hollywood to the World: U.S. and European Struggles for Mastery of the Global Film Industry, 1920-1950,'' New York: Cambridge University Press, p4.</ref>
==Central Casting== When the entertainment industry started to take off in the early 1920s, thousands of people flocked to Hollywood with hopes of becoming the next big star. These hopefuls were called "[[Extra_(acting)|extras]]" because they were the extra people who filled out scenes. The main way to find work at this time was to wait outside the gates of studios, hoping production would hire you on the spot. With little regulation on hiring film extras, many people were exploited while looking for work. In an effort to fix the employment issues and exploitation that plagued the industry, Hays commissioned several studies of the employment conditions in Hollywood. After reviewing the results of the studies, Hays created the [[Central_Casting|Central Casting Corporation]] in 1925 as a way to regulate the hiring of extras in Hollywood.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.centralcasting.com/from-film-extras-to-background-actors/ |title=From Film Extras to Background Actors |publisher=Central Casting |access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref>
==Death== After his retirement, Will H. Hays returned to Sullivan, Indiana, where he died on March 7, 1954.<ref name=obit>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Will Hays, First Film Czar, Dies. Former G.O.P. Leader Was 74. Arbiter of Hollywood's Morals 23 Years Was Postmaster General Under Harding |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=980DE5D81731E43ABC4053DFB566838F649EDE |quote=Will H. Hays, who left President Warren G. Harding's Cabinet to clean up movie morals in the Nineteen Twenties, died today of heart ailment at his home here. He was 74 years old. |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=March 8, 1954 |accessdate=January 12, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Will H. Hays Dies; Former Movie 'Czar' |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/890285142.html?dids=890285142:890285142&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Mar+08%2C+1954&author=&pub=The+Hartford+Courant&desc=Will+H.+Hays+Dies%3B+Former+Movie+%27Czar%27&pqatl=google |quote=Will H. Hays, 74, who left President Harding's Cabinet to clean up movie morals in the roaring 20s, died of a heart condition at his Sullivan home at noon today. |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=March 8, 1954 |accessdate=July 3, 2008 }}</ref> His widow died in 1960.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Mrs. Will H. Hays Dies. Widow of Former 'Czar' of Movie Industry Was 84 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9901E1D91031EF3ABC4850DFBE66838B679EDE |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=August 30, 1960 |accessdate=January 12, 2015 }}</ref>
==Production Code== {{main|United States Motion Picture Production Code of 1930}} The Production Code enumerated three "General Principles":
#No picture shall be produced that will lower the moral standards of those who see it. Hence the sympathy of the audience should never be thrown to the side of crime, wrongdoing, evil or sin. #Correct standards of life, subject only to the requirements of drama and entertainment, shall be presented. #Law, natural or human, shall not be ridiculed, nor shall sympathy be created for its violation.
Specific restrictions were spelled out as "Particular Applications" of these principles:
:*[[Depictions of nudity|Nudity]] and suggestive dances were prohibited. :*The ridicule of religion was forbidden, and ministers of religion were not to be represented as comic characters or villains. :*The depiction of [[illegal drug use]] was forbidden, as well as the use of liquor, "when not required by the plot or for proper characterization." :*Methods of crime (e.g. safe-cracking, arson, smuggling) were not to be explicitly presented. :*References to sex perversions such as homosexuality and venereal disease were forbidden, as were depictions of childbirth. :*The language section banned various words and phrases that were considered to be offensive. :*Murder scenes had to be filmed in a way that would discourage imitations in real life, and brutal killings could not be shown in detail. :*"Revenge in modern times" was not to be justified. :*The sanctity of marriage and the home had to be upheld. :*"Pictures shall not infer that low forms of sex relationship are the accepted or common thing." :*Adultery and illicit sex, although recognized as sometimes necessary to the plot, could not be explicit or justified and were not supposed to be presented as an attractive option. :*Portrayals of [[miscegenation]] were forbidden. :*"Scenes of Passion" were not to be introduced when not essential to the plot. :*"Excessive and lustful kissing" was to be avoided, along with any other treatment that might "stimulate the lower and baser element." :*The [[flag of the United States]] was to be treated respectfully, and the people and history of other nations were to be presented "fairly." :*"[[Vulgarity]]", defined as "low, disgusting, unpleasant, though not necessarily evil, subjects" must be "subject to the dictates of good taste." :*Capital punishment, "[[third-degree methods]]", cruelty to children and animals, prostitution and surgical operations were to be handled with similar sensitivity.

{{Infobox Senator | name = William Samuel Johnson | image = William Samuel Johnson (portrait by Gilbert Stuart).jpg | jr/sr = United States Senator | party = [[Federalist party (United States)|Pro-Administration]] | term = March 4, 1789 – March 4, 1791 | predecessor = Office created | successor = [[Roger Sherman]] | birth_date = October 7, 1727 | birth_place = [[Stratford, Connecticut]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1819|11|14|1727|10|7}} | death_place = [[Stratford, Connecticut]] | resting_place = Christ Episcopal Church Cemetery, Stratford | nationality = [[United States|American]] | state = [[Connecticut]] | spouse = Anne Beach[http://odur.let.rug.nl/~usa/B/wsjohnson/johnson.htm A Biography of William Samuel Johnson (1727–1819)] | profession = [[Politician]], [[Clergyman]] | alma_mater = [[Yale College]] | parents = [[Samuel Johnson (1696–1772)|Samuel Johnson]]
Charity Floyd Nicoll | children = Elizabeth Johnson | relatives = [[Daniel C. Verplanck|Daniel Verplanck]] (son-in-law) | branch = [[Connecticut Military Department|Connecticut Colonial Militia]] | rank = [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] }} '''William Samuel Johnson''' (October 7, 1727 – November 14, 1819) was an early American statesman who was notable for signing the [[United States Constitution]], for representing [[Connecticut]] in the [[United States Senate]], and for serving as the third president of [[Columbia University|King's College]] now known as Columbia University. ==Early life== [[File:Coat of Arms of William Samuel Johnson.svg|175px|thumb|left|Coat of Arms of William Samuel Johnson]] William Samuel Johnson was born in [[Stratford, Connecticut]], on October 7, 1727 to [[Samuel_Johnson_(American_educator)|Samuel Johnson]], a well-known Anglican clergyman and later president of King's ([[Columbia University|Columbia]]) College, and Johnson's first wife, Charity Floyd Nicoll. Johnson received his primary education at home. He then graduated from [[Yale College]] in 1744, going on to receive a master's degree from his alma mater in 1747 (as well as an honorary degree from Harvard the same year). Although Johnson's father urged him to enter the clergy, Johnson decided to pursue a legal career.Self educated in law he quickly established various business connections. Johnson also held a commission in the Connecticut colonial militia for over 20 years, earning the rank of colonel. He also served in the lower house of the Connecticut legislature years 1761 and 1765.{{cite web|title=William Samuel Johnson|url=http://www.let.rug.nl/usa/biographies/william-samuel-johnson/|website=American History}} He was also a member of the colonys supreme court years 1772–74. William Samuel Johnson, also attended the Stamp Act Congress in 1765 and served on the committee that addressed the King arguing the right of the colonies to decide tax policies for themselves.{{cite web|title=William Samuel Johnson|url=https://history.army.mil/books/RevWar/ss/johnson.htm|website=Miltarty History}} ==Career== Although his father urged him to enter the clergy, Johnson decided instead to pursue a legal career. Self-educated in the law, he quickly developed an important clientele and established business connections extending beyond the boundaries of his native colony. He also held a commission in the Connecticut colonial militia for over 20 years, rising to the rank of colonel, and he served in the lower house of the [[Connecticut General Assembly|Connecticut Legislature]] (1761 and 1765) and in the upper house (1766 and 1771–75). Additionally, he was a member of the colony's [[Connecticut Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] (1772–74). He was first attracted to the Patriot cause by what he and his associates considered [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]]'s unwarranted interference in the government of the colonies. He attended the [[Stamp Act Congress]] in 1765, and served on the committee that drafted an address to the King arguing the right of the colonies to decide tax policies for themselves. He opposed the [[Townshend Acts]] passed by Parliament in 1767 to pay for the [[French and Indian War]] and supported the non-importation agreements devised by the colonies to protest taxation without representation. ===American Revolution=== Johnson lived in London from 1767 to 1771, serving as Connecticut's agent in its attempt to settle the colony's title to Indian lands. He sharply criticized British policy toward the colonies. His experience in Britain convinced him that Britain's policy was shaped more by ignorance of American conditions and not through the sinister designs of a wicked government, as many Patriots alleged. As the Patriots became more radical in their demands, Johnson found it difficult to commit himself wholeheartedly to the cause. Although he believed British policy unwise, he found it difficult to break his own connections with the mother country. A scholar of international renown, he had many friends in Britain and among the American Loyalists. As the famous English author, [[Samuel Johnson]], said of him, "Of all those whom the various accidents of life have brought within my notice, there is scarce anyone whose acquaintance I have more desired to cultivate than yours." He was also bound to Britain by religious and professional ties. He enjoyed close associations with the Anglican Church in England and with the scholarly community at Oxford, which awarded him an honorary degree in 1766. Fearing the consequences of independence for both the colonies and the mother country, Johnson sought to avoid extremism and to reach a compromise on the outstanding political differences between the protagonists. He rejected his election to the [[First Continental Congress]], a move strongly criticized by the Patriots, who removed him from his militia command. He was also strongly criticized when, seeking an end to the fighting after Lexington and Concord, he personally visited the British commander, General [[Thomas Gage]]. The incident led to his arrest for communicating with the enemy, but the charges were eventually dropped. He felt that the American Revolution was not necessary and that independence would be bad for everyone concerned.Elizabeth P. McCaughey, "William Samuel Johnson, The Loyal Whig" in William M. Fowler Jr. and Wallace Coyle, eds. ''American Revolution: Changing Perspectives'' (1979), pp. 69–102 ===New nation=== Once independence was achieved, Johnson felt free to participate in the government of the new nation, serving in the [[Congress of the Confederation]] (1785–1787). His influence as a delegate was recognized by his contemporaries. [[Jeremiah Wadsworth]] wrote of him to a friend, "Dr. Johnson has, I believe, much more influence than either you or myself. The Southern Delegates are vastly fond of him." In 1785, the [[Vermont Republic]] granted Johnson a town in the former [[King's College Tract]] in thanks for representing the interests of Vermont before the Continental Congress.{{cite book |author=Swift, Esther M. |title=''Vermont Place-Names, Footprints in History'' |year=1977 |publisher=The Stephen Greene Press |pages=282–283 |isbn=0828902917 }} The town of [[Johnson, Vermont]], the small university [[Johnson State College]], and Johnson Street [http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/odd/archives/002071.asp] in [[Madison, Wisconsin]] bear his name. ===Constitutional Convention=== In 1787, Johnson played a major role as one of the [[Philadelphia Convention]]'s delegates. His eloquent speeches on the subject of representation carried great weight during the debate. He looked to a strong federal government to protect the rights of Connecticut and the other small states from encroachment by their more powerful neighbors. He supported the [[New Jersey Plan]], which called for equal representation of the states in the national legislature. In general, he favored extension of federal authority. He argued that the judicial power "ought to extend to equity as well as law" (the words "in law and equity" were adopted at his motion). The inflexibility of the law had to be tempered by fairness. He denied that there could be treason against a separate state since sovereignty was "in the Union." He opposed prohibition of any [[ex post facto]] law, one which made an act a criminal offense retroactively, because such prohibition implied "an improper suspicion of the National Legislature." Johnson was influential even in the final stages of framing the Constitution. He gave his fullest support to the [[Connecticut Compromise]], which foreshadowed the final Great Compromise, with a national legislature with a Senate that provided equal representation for all states and a House of Representatives based on population. He also served on and chaired the five-member Committee of Style, which framed the final form of the document. In ''[[Miracle at Philadelphia]]'', [[Catherine Drinker Bowen]] called Johnson "the perfect man to preside over these four masters of argument and political strategy [i.e. fellow committee members [[Alexander Hamilton]], [[Gouverneur Morris]], [[James Madison]], and [[Rufus King]]].... His presence on the committee must have been reassuring; the doctor's quiet manner disarmed."Bowen, p.235 of the 1986 edition == References == ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Sources * {{ACMH| url = http://www.history.army.mil/books/RevWar/ss/johnson.htm |article = "William Samuel Johnson" in Soldiers and Statesman by Robert K. Wright Jr. and Morris J. MacGregor Jr.}} * {{CongBio|J000182}} * Graff, Nancy Price. ''Visible Layers of Time: A Perspective on the History and Architecture of Johnson Vermont.'' The University of Vermont, Historic Preservation Program: 1990. * McCaughey, Elizabeth P. "William Samuel Johnson, The Loyal Whig" in William M. Fowler Jr. and Wallace Coyle, eds. ''American Revolution: Changing Perspectives'' (1979), pp. 69–102 * Beardsley, E. Edwards. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rdmfGCDg6YIC&printsec=titlepage ''Life and Times of William Samuel Johnson, LL.D.'' (1876)] ==External links== * {{findagrave|4712}} {{s-start}} {{s-aca}} {{succession box|title=[[Columbia University|President of Columbia College]]|before=[[George Clinton (vice president)|George Clinton]]

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Yoni Wolf | birth_name = Jonathan Avram Wolf | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1979|4|30}} | birth_place = [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], U.S. | image = Why-brussels-2010.jpg | caption = Yoni Wolf performing with Why? in Brussels in 2010 | image_size = 250 | background = solo_singer | alias = Why? (1997–2004) | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative hip hop]]|[[underground hip hop]]|[[indie rock]]}} | years_active = 1997–present | label = {{hlist|[[Anticon]]|[[Mush Records|Mush]]|[[Lex Records|Lex]]}} | associated_acts = [[Why? (American band)|Why?]], [[Greenthink]], [[Clouddead]], [[Reaching Quiet]], [[Hymie's Basement]], Miss Ohio's Nameless, Apogee | website = [http://www.whywithaquestionmark.com/ www.whywithaquestionmark.com/] }} '''Jonathan Avram "Yoni" Wolf''' (born April 30, 1979) is an [[United States|American]] [[alternative hip hop]] and [[indie rock]] musician and co-founder of the record label [[Anticon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alarm-magazine.com/2010/why-introspective-vagabond-rap/|title=Why?: Hip Hop’s Lyrical Transient|publisher=''ALARM Magazine''|first=Drew|last=Fortune|date=December 15, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019165507/http://alarm-magazine.com/2010/why-introspective-vagabond-rap/ |archivedate=October 19, 2012|df=}}</ref>
From 1997 until 2004, Wolf released music under the stage name '''Why?'''. In 2004 he transferred that name onto his [[Why? (American band)|newly founded band]]. Thereafter he has been credited for his solo work as Yoni Wolf.
Prior to the founding of the band Why? in 2004, Wolf had also been a member of numerous other groups, including [[Greenthink]], [[Clouddead]], [[Reaching Quiet]] and [[Hymie's Basement]].
==History== Wolf was born in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] to [[Messianic Judaism|Messianic Jewish]] parents.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ben Ari |first=Gon |title=Why Not |publication-date=July 3, 2009 |newspaper=7 Nights, [[Yedioth Ahronoth]]}}</ref> Before his first year in high school, he discovered an old 4-track in his father's synagogue and began to experiment musically. His forays into rapping, drumming, and poetry followed.
In 1997, while attending art school at the [[University of Cincinnati]], Wolf met fellow student Adam Drucker, aka [[Doseone]], at the semifinals of [[Scribble Jam]]. Along with Doseone, [[Mr. Dibbs]] and his brother [[Josiah Wolf]], he formed the live improvisational group Apogee. The partnership of Wolf and Doseone continued for many years under many guises.
[[File:Why2 (cropped).jpg|thumb|150px|left|Yoni Wolf performing with Why? in [[Brussels]] in 2010]] In 1998 the duo released the album ''[[It's Not Easy Being...]]'' under the name [[Greenthink]]. In 1999, with an expansive roster of featured guests, they released the second Greenthink record ''[[Blindfold (album)|Blindfold]]'', after which they expanded to a trio with the addition of producer [[Odd Nosdam]] and adopted the name [[Clouddead]]. In the same year Wolf released his first solo album under the name Why?, entitled ''Part Time People Cage... or Part Time Key?''.
Beginning in 2000, Clouddead released a series of six 10" vinyl singles on [[Mush Records]]. In 2001 these singles were compiled on CD and released as the group's [[Clouddead (album)|self-titled debut album]].
Following the release of his album ''[[Oaklandazulasylum]]'' in 2003, Wolf enlisted Josiah Wolf on drums, Matt Meldon on guitar, and Doug McDiarmid as a multi-instrumentalist. Wolf decided to transfer his alias onto the new band, and [[Why? (American band)|Why?]] was officially formed.
In 2005, Why? released their debut album ''[[Elephant Eyelash]]''. The album deviated considerably from the sound of Wolf's prior solo work. The group toured much of 2005 in support of the album as a four-piece. However, by the time of their May 2006 tour with [[Islands (band)|Islands]], the group had become a three-piece, as Meldon moved to an island off the coast of [[Seattle]] to live with his girlfriend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southern.net/southern/news/?id%3D90 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090706103524/http://www.southern.net/southern/news/?id=90 |archivedate=July 6, 2009 }}</ref>
For their second album ''[[Alopecia (album)|Alopecia]]'', Why? asked their fans to contribute photographs of their palms for the album's artwork. They released "The Hollows" as the first single, with two different European and US versions, featuring remixes and covers by [[Boards of Canada]], [[Xiu Xiu]], [[Dntel]], [[Half-handed Cloud]], [[Dump (band)|Dump]] and [[Islands (band)|Islands]]. ''Alopecia'' was released in 2008 to very positive reviews.
In 2009, Why? released their third album ''[[Eskimo Snow]]''. The ten songs on the album were recorded during the ''Alopecia'' sessions and are described by Wolf as "the least hip-hop out of anything I've ever been involved with."<ref name=PitchforkEskimo>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/news/35416-whys-yoni-wolf-reveals-new-album-ieskimo-snowi/ |title=WHY?'s Yoni Wolf Reveals New Album: ''Eskimo Snow'' |author=Tom Breihan |date=May 29, 2009 |publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]] |accessdate=May 30, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530212242/http://pitchfork.com/news/35416-whys-yoni-wolf-reveals-new-album-ieskimo-snowi/ |archivedate=May 30, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
On June 27, 2012, the band announced via [[Stereogum]] that they would be releasing their new EP ''[[Sod in the Seed]]'' on August 13 on [[City Slang]]. In the same article they premiered the title track. The song is more upbeat than any of the tracks on ''Eskimo Snow'' and contains rapping, which had been absent on the previous album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stereogum.com/1077502/why-sod-in-the-seed/mp3s/|title=WHY? - "Sod in the Seed"|publisher=''Stereogum''|first=Corbin|last=Goble|date=June 27, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120830075427/http://stereogum.com/1077502/why-sod-in-the-seed/mp3s/|archivedate=August 30, 2012|df=}}</ref>
The band released their fourth album, ''[[Mumps, Etc.]]'' on October 9, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/47309-why-announce-new-album-mumps-etc/|title=WHY? announce new album, Mumps, etc.|publisher=''Pitchfork''|first=Carrie|last=Battan|date=July 30, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130912161844/http://pitchfork.com/news/47309-why-announce-new-album-mumps-etc/|archivedate=September 12, 2013|df=}}</ref>
Wolf suffers from [[Crohn's disease]] and many of his lyrics describe his efforts to cope with the illness.<ref>{{cite web|last=Plasternack|first=Alex|title=Just To Be Grounded: An Interview with Yoni Wolf|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/ezzzp7/just-to-be-grounded-an-interview-with-yoni-wolf-of-why|publisher=Vice|accessdate=31 January 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401213138/https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/ezzzp7/just-to-be-grounded-an-interview-with-yoni-wolf-of-why|archivedate=1 April 2018|df=}}</ref>
==Collaborations== Wolf has produced tracks for other MCs. He produced several tracks for fellow Anticon co-founder [[Pedestrian (rapper)|Pedestrian]]'s album ''[[Volume One: UnIndian Songs]]'' in 2005. He also produced several tracks for [[Serengeti (rapper)|Serengeti]]'s album ''Family and Friends'', as well as providing backup vocals, in 2011.<ref name=PitchforkFamily>{{cite web |url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15639-family-and-friends/ |title=Serengeti – Family and Friends |author=Zach Kelly |date=July 21, 2011 |publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]] |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722141400/http://www.pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15639-family-and-friends/ |archivedate=July 22, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Wolf has released many albums as a member of groups including [[Reaching Quiet]], [[Hymie's Basement]], Miss Ohio's Nameless and Object Beings. He has collaborated with Doseone, [[Odd Nosdam]], [[Fog (band)|Fog]] among others. In 2017, he convinced his label to put out [[The Ophelias (band)|The Ophelias]]' debut LP, and he produced their sophomore LP, ''Almost'', the following year which was also released on [[Joyful Noise Recordings|Joyful Noise]].
==Selected discography== {{Main|Yoni Wolf discography}}
===Albums=== '''Solo''' :* ''Part Time People Cage... or Part Time Key?'' (1999) <small>(as Why?)</small> :* ''[[Oaklandazulasylum]]'' (2003) <small>(as Why?)</small>
'''[[Why? (American band)|Why?]]''' :* ''[[Elephant Eyelash]]'' (2005) :* ''[[Alopecia (album)|Alopecia]]'' (2008) :* ''[[Eskimo Snow]]'' (2009) :* ''[[Mumps, Etc.]]'' (2012) :* ''[[Moh Lhean]]'' (2017)
'''[[Clouddead]]''' <small>(Yoni Wolf with [[Doseone]] & [[Odd Nosdam]])</small> :* ''[[Clouddead (album)|Clouddead]]'' (2001) :* ''[[Ten (Clouddead album)|Ten]]'' (2004)
'''Greenthink''' <small>(Yoni Wolf with Doseone)</small> :* ''It's Not Easy Being...'' (1998) :* ''Blindfold'' (1999)
'''Other collaborations''' :* ''Object Beings'' (2001) <small>(with Doseone & [[Pedestrian (rapper)|Pedestrian]], as Object Beings)</small> :* ''[[In the Shadow of the Living Room]]'' (2002) <small>(with Odd Nosdam, as [[Reaching Quiet]])</small> :* ''[[Hymie's Basement (album)|Hymie's Basement]]'' (2003) <small>(with Andrew Broder, as [[Hymie's Basement]])</small> :* ''Divorcee'' (2014) <small>(with Anna Stewart, as Divorcee)</small> :* ''[[Testarossa (album)|Testarossa]]'' (2016) <small>(with [[Serengeti (rapper)|Serengeti]])</small>
